div.p: The authors would like to thank our industry contacts for their involvement in the formulation of the project and input on the report. The perspective of industry was vital to the project and their time and effort were greatly appreciated.

div.head: Executive Summary
div.p: The potential release of radioactive material during a plant incident, referred to as the source term, is a vital design metric and will be a major focus of advanced reactor licensing. The U.S. Nuclear Regulatory Commission has stated an expectation for advanced reactor vendors to present a mechanistic assessment of the potential source term in their license applications. The mechanistic source term presents an opportunity for vendors to realistically assess the radiological consequences of an incident and may allow reduced emergency planning zones and smaller plant sites. However, the development of a mechanistic source term for advanced reactors is not without challenges, as there are often numerous phenomena impacting the transportation and retention of radionuclides. This project sought to evaluate U.S. capabilities regarding the mechanistic assessment of radionuclide release from core damage incidents at metal fueled, pool-type sodium fast reactors (SFRs). The purpose of the analysis was to identify, and prioritize, any gaps regarding computational tools or data necessary for the modeling of radionuclide transport and retention phenomena. To accomplish this task, a parallelpath analysis approach was utilized, as shown below. One path, led by Argonne and Sandia National Laboratories, sought to perform a mechanistic source term assessment using available codes, data, and models, with the goal to identify gaps in the current knowledge base. The second path, performed by an independent contractor, performed sensitivity analyses to determine the importance of particular radionuclides and transport phenomena in regards to offsite consequences. The results of the two pathways were combined to prioritize gaps in current capabilities.

The primary conclusion of this project is that a mechanistic assessment of radionuclide release from a pool-type, metal fuel SFR core damage incident is possible utilizing current tools and data, with certain limitations. Gaps in models and data regarding some phenomena result in uncertainties, or the use of conservative assumptions, which could make the process of justifying reduced emergency planning zones or plant sites difficult for vendors and also potentially impact design decisions that are dependent on realistic source term analyses. Specifically, three major gap areas dominated the mechanistic source term assessment:

1) Bubble Transport -There are large uncertainties regarding the transport of radionuclides within bubbles in the sodium pool. This pathway could result in a bypass mechanism for radionuclides that would otherwise be largely retained within the sodium pool. Properly characterizing the bubble pathway is essential to a realistic source term assessment, but data and tools in this area are lacking. Gap closure in this area could be accomplished through experiments with nonradioactive elements.

2) In-pin Migration and Release -Due to insufficient data regarding the migration of radionuclides within the fuel pin and subsequent release during fuel pin failure (as described in more detail in ANL-ART-38), bounding radionuclide release fractions from failed fuel pins are necessary. These assumptions impact subsequent steps of the analysis and may produce potentially unrealistic results, such as comparatively large releases of transuranics. Gap closure regarding radionuclide release during fuel pin failure is difficult, but further work to characterize in-pin radionuclide migration is less challenging and currently possible.

3) Aerosol Behavior -The accurate modeling of radionuclide behavior within the cover gas region and containment can be problematic due to the unique chemical forms and interactions associated with SFR radionuclide (and sodium) release. Although conservative assumptions are straightforward to apply regarding selected phenomenological gaps, such as aerosol deposition, other phenomena, such as chemical interactions, are more difficult to address through gross assumptions.

Utilizing the findings of the sensitivity study, the gaps identified during the mechanistic source term analysis were prioritized. In addition, recommendations for future research were developed based on specific aspects of the phenomena gaps. These recommendations (listed below in order of "gap group" prioritization) would significantly reduce the uncertainties noted during the mechanistic source term calculation, and provide a more accurate source term assessment for use during future SFR design efforts and license applications.

div.head: Gap Group Recommendations
div.p: Bubble Transport • Formal completion of the IFR bubble code, including development of documentation and code licensing pathway.

div.head: • Experimentation regarding failed fuel pin blowdown and entrainment of released radionuclides in bubble (cross-cutting research with reactivity effects of channel voiding and structural impacts of failed fuel pin blowdown on neighboring fuel pins).
div.p: • Experimentation regarding removal of radionuclides from bubble traveling through sodium pool.

div.head: In-Pin Migration and Release
div.p: • Continued metal fuel PIE to determine radionuclide migration within fuel pin during irradiation.
• Experimentation regarding radionuclide release from failed high burnup fuel pins at high temperatures (above fuel melting point) in liquid sodium.

div.head: Aerosol Behavior • Continued development of SFR version of MELCOR.
div.p: • Assessment of available data regarding deposition/condensation/chemical interactions within cover gas region and containment.

div.head: Hold-up/Leakage
div.p: • Response of reactor head seals during transient conditions.

div.head: Vaporization
div.p: • Investigation of non-homogeneous mixing of radionuclides in liquid sodium.

div.head: Dispersion
div.p: • Assessment of applicability of dose conversion factors and deposition assumptions to chemical and physical radionuclide forms likely in SFR radionuclide release.

div.head: Introduction
div.p: The U.S. Nuclear Regulatory Commission licenses and regulates the Nation's civilian use of radioactive materials to protect public health and safety, promote the common defense and security, and protect the environment.

div.head: -U.S. Nuclear Regulatory Commission Mission Statement
div.p: As stated above, the primary mission of the U.S. Nuclear Regulatory Commission (NRC) is the protection of the public and environment from the accidental release of radioactivity. With this in mind, it is not surprising that there is such strong emphasis on the potential release of radioactivity (the source term) during the NRC reactor licensing process. While the current light-water reactor fleet was licensed through the use of conservative, bounding source term analyses, the NRC has repeatedly indicated an expectation that future advanced reactors license applications will include a mechanistic assessment of potential radionuclide releases [1][2][3]. While the use of realistic source term assessment models provides advanced reactor vendors the opportunity to potentially reduce emergency planning zones and the size of plant sites, properly accounting for the multitude of possible radionuclides transport and retention phenomena is a challenging task. In addition, the ability to perform a realistic source term assessment is a vital tool during the reactor design process, as it promotes the use of risk-informed design decisions.

Since the successful operation of the EBR-II experimental reactor program, it has been apparent that a metal fueled, sodium-cooled fast reactor (SFR) has a number of safety and performance characteristics that make it an attractive candidate as an advanced reactor concept. Currently, there are multiple U.S. industry vendors proposing metal fueled, pool-type SFR designs. As part of a project to identify and address potential future impediments to SFR licensing, an effort was established to characterize the U.S. capabilities for the mechanistic assessment of radionuclide release following a core damage incident at a metal fueled, pool-type SFR. The goal of this work was to identify and prioritize gaps in the current computational capabilities, and the associated knowledge base, regarding the mechanistic assessment of an SFR source term.

div.head: Background
div.p: Beginning in FY14, under the auspices of the U.S. Department of Energy (DOE) Regulatory Technology Development Plan (RTDP), Argonne National Laboratory (Argonne) initiated a study of possible impediments to the licensing of an SFR in the U.S. 1 The issues highlighted by this study included the selection of licensing basis events, the regulatory treatment of sodium fires, and the certification of seismic isolators, amongst others. However, only one topic, the development of a mechanistic source term (MST), was found to have both high regulatory importance and a possible "long" lead-time to resolution. Therefore, this issue was selected for further investigation under the RTDP. Among the findings of ANL-ART-3, two noted gaps were selected for follow-on work in FY16:

1) Metal Fuel Radionuclide Release Fractions -ANL-ART-3 noted that it was unclear whether sufficient data and experience existed to develop radionuclide release fractions from failed metal fuel pins to the primary sodium.

2) Trial MST Calculation -ANL-ART-3 noted that no single, comprehensive computer code existed for an SFR MST. Instead, there were several computational tools that could analyze separate parts of the calculation. It was recommended to conduct a trial MST to determine the sufficiency of this approach and the adequacy of the related computational tools.

The first gap was explored in ANL-ART-38 [6], which conducted a review of metal fuel data and determined radionuclide release fractions from failed metal fuel to the primary sodium under a variety of temperature conditions. The second gap, regarding MST computational tools and the need for a trial MST calculation is explored in detail here.

div.head: Methodology and Report Structure
div.p: As stated at the beginning of this section, the goal of the trial MST calculation is to gauge the adequacy of current computational tools and the associated knowledge base for the assessment of an SFR MST. To accomplish this goal, a parallel-path analysis methodology was developed. As shown in Figure 1-3, the methodology consists of both an MST calculation and a simplified source term sensitivity analysis. The MST calculation uses best-estimate codes and models in an attempt to realistically assess the transport and release of radionuclides. The goal of this analysis pathway is to identify any gaps in current computational capabilities or the associated knowledge base. The sensitivity calculation uses simplified radionuclide transport and retention models to conduct a parametric evaluation. The purpose of the sensitivity calculation is to rank transport and retention phenomena in terms of their importance on offsite consequences (offsite dose and land contamination). There were several reasons for the decision to conduct a separate sensitivity calculation. First, simplified models were more conducive to parametric evaluations than the mechanistic models, some of which were time consuming to utilize. Second, an independent contractor was selected to perform the sensitivity calculation, in an effort to assure possible biases in the MST calculation would not influence the ranking of phenomena. The report structure follows that of the analysis methodology, as shown in Figure 1234. Section 2 provides an overview of the trial MST calculation, including the models and data utilized and identified gaps.

Section 3 contains an overview of the sensitivity analysis, noting those isotopes and transport/retention phenomena of highest importance to offsite consequence. Finally, Section 4 prioritizes the gaps found in the trial MST in Section 2, using the insights from the sensitivity analysis in Section 3.

div.head: Trial Mechanistic Source Term Calculation
div.p: The purpose of the trial MST calculation was to utilize current modeling tools, and the associated knowledge base, in a comprehensive test of their adequacy in performing a complete SFR MST analysis. However, to properly gauge the suitability of the data and tools for the future licensing of SFRs, the trial MST had to include several key characteristics:

1) The trial MST must attempt to account for all pertinent radionuclide transport/retention phenomena regarding SFR core damage incidents. This includes exercising available tools and data. If it is determined to not be possible to model a phenomenon, the gap should be noted and analysis assumptions may be made to allow the MST calculation to proceed.

2) The modeling tools should be comparable to those traditionally used in nuclear safety analyses (i.e., the computational tools should not require extreme computing capabilities, such as super computers, and execution times must be reasonable, to allow for uncertainty quantification).

3) The reactor design analyzed must be prototypic of those currently proposed by the SFR industry, with an emphasis on maintaining consistency of the radionuclide barriers and transport/retention phenomena.

The first key characteristic, regarding the modeling of radionuclide transport/retention phenomena, will be discussed in detail in each of the following subsections. At the end of each subsection, there is a table discussing the phenomena modeled during that analysis step, as shown in the example Table 2-1. The table notes the phenomenon considered, how it was modeled, whether there was a gap identified, and finally if a gap was noted, the resulting impact on the trial MST calculation. This information is used in Section 4 (in conjunction with the Section 3 sensitivity analysis) to rank the identified gaps and prioritize future research. Also, as will be described in Section 2.2, assessing models and data associated with all pertinent phenomena was particularly challenging and resulted in the inclusion of two separate transient analyses. The modeling of transport/retention phenomena also highlights the potential confusion regarding the meaning of "mechanistic." In some industries, mechanistic modeling is taken to represent models based on first-principles, such as physics-based rather than data-driven models. In SECY-93-092 [1], the NRC defined the characteristics of an MST by the following:

A mechanistic source term is the result of an analysis of fission product release based on the amount of cladding damage, fuel damage, and core damage resulting from the specific accident sequences being evaluated. It is developed using best-estimate phenomenological models of the transport of the fission products from the fuel through the reactor coolant system, through all holdup volumes and barriers, taking into account mitigation features, and finally, into the environs.

For the analysis conducted here, the NRC MST definition is interpreted to imply that phenomena are represented as realistically as possible, using any available models, whether physics-based or data-driven.

The second key characteristic highlights the type of modeling tools employed. Computational tools exist that simulate chemical interactions on the atomic-scale, and computational fluid dynamics could model primary sodium flow conditions in 3-D. However, utilizing such programs for an MST assessment would require extreme computational capabilities (and validating such high-fidelity codes could pose an additional challenge for future licensing efforts). Therefore, the tools used for the trial MST should be comparable to those traditionally used in nuclear safety analyses.
The third key characteristic, regarding consistency with industry SFR designs, is discussed in detail in Section 2.1.

div.head: Reference Reactor
div.p: As described at the beginning of this section, one of the prerequisites for the trial MST calculation was to maintain consistency with industry SFR designs, particularly the radionuclide barriers. Table 2-2 provides an overview of U.S. SFR vendor reactor designs. All three U.S. vendors utilize metal fuel, pool-type designs. Both burners and breed/burn designs have been proposed. Generally, the radionuclide barriers are the same across all three designs (fuel matrix, cladding, primary sodium, primary system boundary, containment). However, vented fuel concepts have been discussed, which would signify a deviation from historic U.S. SFR designsfoot_0 . A reference reactor design was selected that is representative of the designs currently being proposed by the SFR industry. A 1000 MWth (380MWe) pool-type SFR design was selected, with the characteristics shown in Table 2-3, which was based on previous Argonne SFR design concepts. An SFR design larger than some industry concepts was purposefully selected to ensure an accurate investigation of source term phenomena. A very small SFR may have an insignificant potential source term, which could lead to the dismissal of phenomenological uncertainties that could be significant for the safety analysis of a larger reactor. The reference reactor uses a sodium-bonded ternary U-Pu-Zr fuel, separated into three core fuel batches. The reference design is an actinide burner (the sensitivity study reviewed in Section 3 examines the impact of the use of a breeder core). As shown in Figure 2-1, the fuel pins of the reference reactor are slightly over three meters in length, with a fission gas plenum approximately one and a half times the length of the active fuel. The U-Pu-Zr is surrounded by a sodium bond, which maintains thermal contact with the HT-9 cladding when the fuel is at low burnup. The three fuel batches, described in Table 2-4, are assumed to have burnup levels at ~2%, 5%, and 10%. A simplified schematic of the reactor vessel layout is shown in Figure 2-2. The reference reactor utilizes a DRACS emergency decay heat removal system. Detailed properties regarding the reactor system, which will be utilized in subsequent sections, are presented in Table 2-5. The reactor containment, described in Table 2-6, is similar to that of a large-dry PWR containment, but on a smaller scale. 3.00 (435) 6.74 (977) 1 At normal operating temperatures

div.head: Trial MST Calculation Overview
div.p: The trial MST calculation involves numerous analysis steps, with each step including multiple subanalyses. Figure 2-3 presents a graphical overview of the MST trial calculation. To aid the reader in following the calculation process, symbols for each calculation step are present at the bottom of the following pages, which highlight the step of the analysis currently under examination. The trial MST calculation begins with the modeling of the transient scenario. This is followed by the determination of the in-pin radionuclide distribution prior to fuel pin failure. Next is the analysis of radionuclide release post-fuel pin failure. Bubble transport through the sodium pool follows fuel pin failure, along with radionuclide release from the sodium pool to the cover gas region. Analyses of radionuclide behavior in the cover gas region and containment are next, with the final step being offsite radionuclide dispersion.

The trial MST calculation was conducted through a collaboration between Argonne and Sandia National Laboratories (SNL). As shown in Figure 234, Argonne performed the initial five steps of the analysis, to the point of radionuclide release to the cover gas region. From there, the analysis split (as will be described in Section 2.7), with SNL leading an analysis of radionuclide behavior in the cover gas region and containment utilizing a developmental version of CONTAIN-LMR, while Argonne conducted a similar analysis using a surrogate computer code. Each of the following subsections provide a summary of the calculation steps. The subsections begin with an overview of the phenomena involved and the methodology utilized to model the phenomena. This is followed by two further subsections that describe the application of the methodology for the two transient scenarios under consideration. As mentioned previously, each subsection ends with a summary of the phenomena modeled, including the identification of gaps.

div.head: Transient Scenario Modeling
div.p: As stated in the MST analysis requirements at the beginning of this section, it was desired to model SFR transient scenarios that involved all pertinent source term phenomena related to SFR core damage transients. However, there were some phenomena that were mutually exclusive to certain types of transients. Therefore, two reactor transient scenarios were selected for the MST calculation. These scenarios represent two distinct types of SFR core damage transients. One scenario with prolonged elevated core temperatures, which results in fuel pin failures without fuel melting, and another scenario with a rapid rise in fuel temperatures resulting in fuel melting but with the remainder of the primary system at near-nominal conditions.

Phenomena related to extremely unlikely metal fuel SFR transients, such as core disruption accidents (core energetics) or double vessel failure with loss of primary sodium, were excluded from the trial MST calculation. It is assumed that SFR vendors will perform analyses that demonstrate the extremely low frequency of occurrence, or impossibility, of such events for their reactor design, therefore alleviating the vendor from the obligation to perform MST assessments for such reactor transients. It is the responsibility of the vendor to provide the necessary justification for this exclusion (or if the choice is made to include such scenarios, perform the necessary analyses to demonstrate that regulatory criteria are satisfied).

The proper modeling of benign termination of transient scenarios (i.e., the avoidance of core energetics) is considered here as an accident analysis modeling concern, rather than a source term modeling issue. However, as will be seen in the following subsections, when issues with benign termination modeling were encountered, they were noted to assist in future research and development efforts.

div.head: Key Project Point
div.p: Phenomena related to extremely unlikely metal fuel SFR transients, such as core disruption (energetics) and loss of primary sodium accidents, were excluded from the trial MST calculation, as it is assumed that SFR vendors will perform analyses justifying the exclusion of such transients from those that require a MST assessment, due to the extremely low frequency, or impossibility, of occurrence.

div.head: Key Project Point
div.p: It was necessary to select two transient scenarios to encompass all relevant radionuclide transport/retention phenomena. The two transient scenarios were chosen to provide the desired core damage conditions, and their selection should not be misconstrued as an indication of their specific importance to future SFR licensing efforts.

div.head: Protected Loss of Flow (and Heat Sink) with Degraded Decay Heat Removal
div.p: -PLOF+ -Slow rise of core temperatures -Pin failures due to eutectic penetration with no bulk fuel melting -Very high primary system temperatures

div.head: Severe Unprotected Transient Overpower
div.p: -UTOP+ -Rapid rise in core temperatures -Fuel melting resulting in pin failures -Near-nominal primary system conditions

div.head: Methodology
div.p: The analysis tool chosen for the simulation of the transient scenarios, and the prediction and characterization of core damage, was the U.S. SFR severe accident code SAS4A/SASSYS-1 version 5.1 [7]. Originally developed in the 1960s, SAS4A/SASSYS-1 is now widely used both domestically and internationally for the assessment of SFR transient scenarios. Although SAS4A/SASSYS-1 has not formally been used as part of the U.S. NRC reactor licensing process in the past, there are current Argonne projects investigating the requirements for regulatory acceptability [8].

SAS4A/SASSYS-1 is capable of assessing reactor system conditions, such as primary and intermediate circuit temperatures and pressures, as well as determining detailed core conditions. SAS4A/SASSYS-1 contains several internal modules, which are used for the prediction of fuel pin failure and relocation of molten fuel. It is important to note that many of these modules were originally developed for oxide fuel as part of the Clinch River Breeder Reactor Project (CRBRP). Following the termination of the CRBRP, many of these modules were updated to include metal fuel phenomena during the Integral Fast Reactor (IFR) project in the 1980s and early 1990s. However, this work ceased with the termination of the IFR project in 1994, and the metal fuel core damage models were not formally completed. This is a known gap regarding the modeling of metal fuel SFR core damage accidents and there are efforts currently underway at Argonne to complete the development of the metal fuel core damage modules, in collaboration with the Korean Atomic Energy Research Institute (KAERI) [9]. While code development work is ongoing, the latest SAS4A/SASSYS-1 core damage models were not yet available for use as part of this project. Therefore, for the current MST trial calculation, what is referred to here as the legacy SAS4A/SASSYS-1 metal fuel core damage models were utilized. As will be described in subsequent sections, the limitations of the legacy SAS4A/SASSYS-1 core models required several modifications and assumptions to the trial MST calculation. Any such actions are noted in their respective sections, with a discussion of possible impacts on the MST trial calculation.

The SAS4A/SASSYS-1 model of the reference reactor contained three channels to model the core, each representing one of the fuel batches shown in Table 2-4. The three-channel design was selected to simplify the analysis and expedite code run-times. SAS4A/SASSYS-1 is capable of more detailed core models, including the use of separate channels for each fuel assembly within the core. These options could be used if a vendor wished to characterize core damage with greater precision than the analysis presented here. For the trial MST calculation, the emphasis was on demonstrating the analysis capabilities. The following two subsections describe the results of the SAS4A/SASSYS-1 simulations for the two transient scenarios.

div.head: Protected Loss of Flow with Degraded Decay Heat Removal (PLOF+)
div.p: The first transient scenario modeled was a protected loss of flow with severely degraded decay heat removal capabilities, referred to here as a PLOF+ 3 . This scenario could represent a loss of offsite power (assuming no emergency diesel generator or other source of AC power) coupled with degraded emergency decay heat removal. Such an event could be caused by extreme weather conditions, such as a very severe winter storm, that disables the electrical grid while also causing snow and ice to accumulate on the DRACS inlets, significantly reducing the DRACS performance for some period of time.

The timeline of the PLOF+ transient is shown in Table 2-7. The scenario begins with the loss of primary flow and heat removal through the intermediate loop and balance of plant. All pumps are assumed to coastdown successfully. Soon after this event, the reactor protection system causes a reactor SCRAM due to a reduction in primary pump discharge pressure. The DRACS system is assumed to be degraded from time zero, with restoration occurring after three days (72 hours). The analysis time is seven days following the initiation of the transient. This time period was chosen based on simulations, which showed that primary system temperatures return to near-nominal conditions at this time. The PLOF+ scenario was modeled using SAS4A/SASSYS-1 and the input described in Section 2.2.1. The results of this simulation can be seen in Figure 2-5, which includes a ten hour steady-state period at the start of the simulation. Following the initiation of the transient, core and primary system temperatures initially drop, as reactor shutdown occurs. However, absent a heat removal pathway, core and primary system temperatures soon begin to increase. By three days, fuel pin cladding temperatures are around 875°C, with hot pool temperatures approaching 850°C. The slight difference between the hot pool and cold pool temperatures is a consequence of the small amount of residual heat removal through the degraded DRACS. Temperatures begin to fall following the initiation of decay heat removal after three days. By seven days, core and primary system temperatures are near nominal temperatures at 100% power.

As Figure 2-5 shows, fuel pin failure occurs at different times for the three fuel batches, even though they are all at approximately the same temperature. The unique fuel batch pin failure times are largely a result of the different internal fuel pin pressures. Channel C is the first fuel batch to experience pin failure, as it represents the highest pressure fuel pins (at ~10% burnup). This is followed by the failure of fuel pins in Channel B, and finally fuel pin failure of the lowest burnup fuel in Channel A. The properties of each fuel batch at the time of failure are shown in Table 2-8. For the analysis conducted here, it is assumed that all fuel pins within the fuel batch (60 assemblies ´ 271 pins = 16,260 pins per fuel batch) fail at the same time. This is a simplifying assumption, as the assemblies, and pins within the assemblies, will experience different coolant conditions and have slightly different internal pressures. As stated at the beginning of this section, it is possible to increase the number of channels in SAS4A/SASSYS-1 for greater precision, but that was not the focus of the current analysis. The legacy SAS4A/SASSYS-1 internal modules for the modeling of fuel pin failure appear to produce a reasonable result, when compared to past testingfoot_3 . This is not surprising, as the SAS4A/SASSYS-1 internal module for the prediction of fuel failure without fuel melting (module DEFORM-5) utilizes correlations based on experimental testing [7,10]. For example, past tests have shown a cladding penetration rate of approximately 0.005 to 0.01 µm per second for U-Pu-Zr fuel with HT-9 cladding in the 700 to 750°C temperature range [11]. The reference reactor fuel has a cladding thickness of 560 µm. This translates to complete cladding penetration in 56,000 to 112,000 seconds (15 to 31 hours). However, complete cladding penetration is not needed for fuel pin failure to occur for fuel batches B and C, as they are at high internal pin pressures. Therefore, fuel pin failure can occur sooner, which aligns with the results from SAS4A/SASSYS-1. Fuel Batch A, which is at relatively low internal pin pressure, experiences fuel pin failure only after subjected to temperatures over 700°C for over 13 hours.

div.head: Severe Unprotected Transient Overpower (UTOP+)
div.p: The second transient scenario modeled was a severe unprotected transient overpower, referred to here as UTOP+ 6 . As discussed at the beginning of this section, this scenario was selected to represent the class of SFR transients that may involve fuel melting, and the particular UTOP+ scenario chosen here is likely a very low frequency event, and depending on the reactor design, may not need a detailed MST analysis. However, as explained later in this subsection, such a severe UTOP+ scenario was selected due to several modeling and data constraints.

As discussed in Section 2.2.1, the metal fuel damage models of SAS4A/SASSYS-1 were not formally completed before the termination of the IFR project. While SAS4A/SASSYS-1 was able to successfully complete the analysis of the PLOF+ scenario, the modeling of the UTOP+ scenario was more challenging due to the extent of fuel melting and relocation. The UTOP+ scenario involved SAS4A/SASSYS-1 internal modules that were not needed in the PLOF+ analysis. These modules, although capable of successful execution as part of SAS4A/SASSYS-1 simulation, can be difficult to utilize due to incomplete development efforts. Therefore, for the UTOP+ analysis conducted here, the simulation insights from SAS4A/SASSYS-1 were coupled with experimental results from the metal fuel transient overpower tests conducted at the TREAT facility in the mid-to-late 1980s.

To permit the use of TREAT results within the analysis, a UTOP+ scenario was created that resulted in similar fuel conditions as those seen in the M-Series TREAT tests. Per Table 2-9, the fuel pin at the lowest burnup level (1.9%) was able to withstand the transient overpower without fuel pin failure (although internal fuel melting did occur). Although the two fuel pins at higher burnup levels experienced less fuel melting than the pin at lower burnup, the higher internal pin pressures caused both to experience cladding failure between 9.5 and 11 seconds after the initiation of the transient.

A UTOP+ scenario was created, using the reference reactor design, that resulted in fuel conditions similar to those experienced during the TREAT M-Series tests. Since very high power levels were reached over short time periods in the TREAT tests, the UTOP+ scenario had to be extremely severe. Fuel conditions of the TREAT test could only be matched using a $0.075 per second reactivity insertion, coupled with reduced radial inherent reactivity feedback. As stated at the beginning of this section, this is an extremely unlikely transient scenario, whose purpose is to create certain core conditions for the subsequent MST analysis. The inclusion of the specific UTOP+ scenario in the current analysis should not be misconstrued as an indication of its importance to the future licensing of SFR.

The UTOP+ transient event timeline is provided in Table 2-10. The transient begins with the initiation of the reactivity insertion. The reactor protection system is assumed to fail despite the high neutron flux readings. The SAS4A/SASSYS-1 simulation continued until 11.5 seconds, when the extent of molten fuel movement and relocation caused the termination of the simulation. As can be seen, reactor power climbs steadily, to almost 400% at approximately nine seconds, before negative reactivity from molten fuel movement within the fuel pins lowers reactor power. However, the external reactivity insertion continues, driving power above 400% before fuel pin failure and molten fuel movement out of the fuel pin and core region causes power to rapidly decrease. The reactor reaches a peak power level of ~450% at 11 seconds before fuel pin failures begin to occur, which is almost identical to the TREAT M-Series failures that occurred between 9.5 and 11 seconds at 400 to 440% power. Unlike the PLOF+ scenario, where it is assumed that all fuel pins within a fuel batch fail when SAS4A/SASSYS-1 predicts fuel pin failure, only a fraction of the fuel pins within Batch B and C are assumed to experience melting and cladding failure. This change in assumptions is based on the accident phenomena. In the PLOF+ sequence, the reactor is shutdown, but sufficient decay heat removal is unavailable. The failure of fuel pins has essentially no effect on the decay heat generation. Therefore, the core continues to increase in temperature and fuel pin failures continue. In the UTOP+ scenario, the reactor is at greater than 100% power. When molten fuel relocates (both inside and outside of the fuel pin) to an area beyond, or on the periphery, of the active core region, negative reactivity is introduced and reactor power decreases. Therefore, it is very unlikely that all 120 assemblies in fuel batches B and C would experience complete failure before sufficient negative reactivity was introduced to end the transient scenario 7 . Based on this fact, it was assumed that the equivalent of five complete assemblies (5 assemblies

´ 271 pins = 1,355 pins) experienced fuel melting and failure in both fuel batch B and C. The fuel pin failure information is summarized in Several of these phenomena are central to accurate transient analysis modeling, but are only tangentially important to the source term calculation. The first phenomenon is the benign termination of accident sequences, meaning the avoidance of recriticality or energetics. As stated previously, SAS4A/SASSYS-1 core damage models were not able to complete the UTOP+ transient analysis, but the scenario was purposefully designed in such a way to utilize the results of the TREAT experiments to resolve gaps. This gap in modeling is also currently being addressed through code development work at Argonne.
The second phenomenon was the prediction of fuel pin failure, performed here by SAS4A/SASSYS-1.

Again, there are known deficiencies with the SAS4A/SASSYS-1 models, which are currently being addressed, but the code results appeared reasonable (when compared to experimental results) for the PLOF+ scenario. Next was the phenomena related to molten fuel relocation in the UTOP+ transient. This gap did not become a major factor in the source term calculation performed here, as radionuclide release is based on the percentage of molten fuel, not relocation within the fuel channel (as will be described in Section 2.4). Lastly, the modeling of primary system conditions, such as temperature and pressure, was also performed by SAS4A/SASSYS-1, and is not considered a modeling gap, as SAS4A/SASSYS-1 is used internationally for the prediction of primary system conditions during SFR transient scenarios.

div.head: In-pin Radionuclide Distribution
div.p: As with any nuclear fuel, during the irradiation of sodium-bonded metal fuel, fission products are formed. The characteristics and distribution of fission products within the fuel pin during irradiation is an important factor in determining the extent of radionuclide release after cladding failure. This section assesses the distribution of radionuclides within the fuel pins of the reference reactor, prior to the transient scenario and fuel pin failure.

div.head: Methodology
div.p: This analysis step can be split into two stages. First, the radionuclides within the fuel pin at the time of the transient must be determined. This is followed by an assessment of the distribution of the radionuclides within the fuel pin at the time of transient. The first step is straightforward, requiring only details about the reactor fuel type, burnup conditions, etc., and an isotope generation and depletion code, such as ORIGEN [14], which was used here. The second part of the analysis, concerning radionuclide distribution within the fuel pin, is more complex.

Before noting the methodology used to develop radionuclide migration fractions for the reference reactor, it is important to describe the phenomena that occur within metal fuel pins during irradiation. As shown in Figure 2-8, before irradiation, the fresh fuel matrix is surrounded by bond sodium. By approximately one percent burnup, the creation of fission products, particularly fission gases, within the fuel matrix causes the fuel matrix to expand (both radially and axially), coming in contact with the cladding and extruding much of the bond sodium to the upper fission gas plenum. Once the burnup exceeds approximately two percent, the porosity of the fuel matrix, formed by the creation of fission products, begins to interconnect.

The interconnected porosity provides a pathway for gaseous fission products to migrate to the fission gas plenum. However, non-gaseous radionuclides also migrate within the fuel matrix and to the bond sodium. The interconnected porosity of the fuel matrix also allows bond sodium to become "logged" within the fuel matrix.

Determining the behavior of radionuclides within the fuel pin during irradiation is a difficult process. For comparison, in the development of source term models for LWR fuels, very simple models, such as the Booth model [15], were used to describe radionuclide migration and release from fuel, where the parameters of the model were tailored to reproduce experimental results. The formation of interconnected porosity in metal fuel provides not only an opportunity for migration of radionuclides from the fuel matrix but also for radionuclides to react and form chemical compounds that could affect their migration.
Although important insights could be gained from a first principles approach to modeling these reactions and the processes affecting migration, in this analysis an empirical approach is used.

Most data regarding radionuclide migration come from post-irradiation examinations (PIEs) of irradiated metal fuel pins. As part of a recent study of radionuclide release from failed metal fuel pins (ANL-ART-38 [6]), Argonne analyzed PIEs of irradiated metal fuel pins. The PIE data were coupled with information from past fuel pin failures to develop estimates of radionuclide migration within the fuel pin. This report formed the basis of the radionuclide migration fraction estimates described in the following subsection. The reference reactor contains three fuel batches, each at different burnup levels. It is assumed that the fuel within each fuel batch is at approximately the same burnup level and that radionuclide migration within the fuel pins of each batch is also approximately the same. For some radionuclides, such as the noble gases, there is considerable PIE available regarding their migration within the fuel pin during irradiation, and the uncertainty associated with their behavior is small. However, for other elements, there is significantly less data available (a gap noted in ANL-ART-38). When data were lacking or uncertainty was large, conservative estimates were made regarding radionuclide migration from the fuel matrix. In this case, conservative means that migration from the fuel matrix to the bond sodium or plenum region was assumed to be on the high-side of available data. Based on the methodology from ANL-ART-38, a minimum migration fraction of 0.1% of the pin inventory was used.

div.head: Results
div.p: Since this analysis step assesses fuel pin conditions prior to the initiation of the transient, the results are the same for both the PLOF+ and UTOP+ scenarios. The radionuclide inventory calculation was completed first, utilizing ORIGEN to determine the inventory in each of the three fuel batches for the reference reactor fuel type and irradiation conditions. The results of this calculation are provided in Appendix A.1 for the isotopes considered for source term analyses, which are provided in those elements noted in NUREG-1465 [16], and also uranium. In total, over 750 isotopes were recorded and assessed for the MST calculation 8 . The analysis of radionuclide migration within the fuel pin was completed next, using insights from ANL-ART-38. The results of the analysis can be found in Table 2-14. The migration estimates shown are for metal fuel at the burnup levels of the three fuel batches (~2%, 5%, and 10%). As the results show, the fraction of the noble gases present in the plenum increases significantly between 2% and 5% burnup, but begins to level-off as burnup approaches 10%. The available data suggest the iodine migration to the bond sodium is fairly burnup independent. Cesium is one of the most mobile radionuclides, with approximately half of the cesium inventory in the bond sodium by 10% burnup. New data suggest strontium migration may be larger than previously thought 9 . The noble metals and lanthanides experience relatively little migration, with the exception of europium, which appears to exhibit behavior similar to that of cesium. Past tests have observed very small fractions of plutonium dissolved in the bond sodium during prolonged irradiation [18]. Therefore, the minimum migration fraction of 0.1% of the inventory was used. While calculating the decay of radionuclides and their daughter products is straightforward, the decay analysis becomes difficult due to the location of the parent/daughter within the fuel pin. For example, some isotopes of krypton within the fission gas plenum will decay into rubidium. The daughter product rubidium will still be present within the fission gas plenum once it is formed (although it may condense or settle onto the bond sodium in the plenum). Therefore, the decay calculation had to account for the location of each parent isotope within the fuel pin.

For each of the three fuel batches, ORIGEN was used to assess the decay of each radionuclide within the fuel pin. Separate ORIGEN calculations were conducted for each region of the fuel pin (plenum/bond sodium and fuel matrix) to ensure that daughter products would be placed at the proper location.

Significant effort was involved with properly tracking isotopes within the fuel and ensuring the multiple ORIGEN inputs were correct. The results of these calculations can be found in Appendix A.1. In general, there is a significant reduction in the radionuclide inventory of the fuel pin due to the 22-32 hours of decay.

div.head: Summary
div.p: Several phenomena were modeled during this analysis step, as shown in Table 2-15. First, the formation of radionuclides during irradiation was determined using ORIGEN. This was followed by an assessment of the migration of radionuclides within the fuel pin during irradiation. There are no computer codes that simulate this process. Instead, the findings from a recent Argonne study (ANL-ART-38) were used as the basis for the migration fraction estimates. These estimates are based on the analysis of past metal fuel PIE data and fuel failure incidents. A partial gap exists due to insufficient data regarding radionuclide migration for several elements important to the source term (such as, I, Te, Ba, Sr, and Eu). Further detail on these gaps is provided in ANL-ART-38 [6]. Due to this uncertainty, what is believed to be, conservative migration fractions were used for several elements. Lastly, for the PLOF+ transient, radionuclide decay within the fuel pin occurs after reactor shutdown, but before fuel pin failure. ORIGEN was utilized to conduct the analysis, but significant analyst effort was also necessary to prepare the multiple ORIGEN inputs that represented different regions of the three fuel batches, which was necessary for proper radionuclide tracking within the fuel pin.

div.head: Failed Pin Radionuclide Release
div.p: Once the pre-transient in-pin migration of radionuclides has been established, and the transient scenario modeled, the release of radionuclides from the fuel pin to the primary sodium can be addressed. This step requires several modeling approaches and a multitude of individual analyses.

div.head: Methodology
div.p: As with in-pin radionuclide migration, it is important to review radionuclide release phenomena before describing the methodology to account for the phenomena. Radionuclide release from failed metal fuel pins is quite different for the two transient scenarios examined here. For the case where the fuel pins fail due to extended exposure to elevated temperatures, with no bulk fuel melting, pin failure is predominately caused by eutectic penetration weakening the cladding in conjunction with cladding hoop stress caused by high internal pin pressures. In metal fuel, the highest fuel pin temperatures usually occur at the top of the active fuel column, due to the high thermal conductivity of the metal fuel and coolant. Therefore, cladding degradation in loss-of-heat-removal events is also generally greatest at the top of the fuel pin.

Figure 2-9 graphically depicts the phenomena that occur when a metal fuel pins fails without bulk fuel melting. The failure of the cladding occurs near the top of the active fuel column, near the boundary of the fission gas plenum region (and where extruded bond sodium has collected). The pressure differential between the fuel pin and the coolant channel can be high. Internal pin pressures can be over 7MPa (~1000psi) for high burnup fuel pins. Conversely, the coolant channel may be at approximately 0.3MPa (~45psi) during loss-of-primary-flow events. The pressure differential results in an immediate blowdown of the fuel pin after cladding failure. The high-pressure vapor and gases in the fission gas plenum push the bond sodium (and radionuclides contained within) out of the fuel pin and into the coolant channel. The rapid depressurization temporarily voids the coolant channel and forms a bubble(s) composed of a mix of radionuclide gases, vapors, and aerosols, and also sodium vapor and aerosol. Radionuclides and bond sodium that were in the liquid form within the fuel pin may now vaporize due to the sudden decrease in pressure. In general, little to no fuel from the fuel matrix is lost to the coolant channel, due to the compatibility of the fuel and sodium coolant.

The process is slightly different if bulk fuel melting occurs. For a scenario such as the UTOP+ transient described in previous sections, which has a rapid rise in fuel temperatures, bulk fuel melting occurs prior to cladding failure. As shown in Figure 2-10, a cavity of molten fuel (and fission products) forms within the fuel matrix. Depending on the particular scenario, the molten fuel cavity may reach the cladding causing pin failure, or the molten fuel cavity may extend to the fission gas plenum and result in molten fuel movement into the fission gas plenum region. The latter is assumed to occur for the UTOP+ scenario here (and was observed in the TREAT M-Series tests). The molten fuel is driven into the plenum region due to the expansion of fission gases contained within. The movement of molten fuel into the plenum region results in the introduction of negative reactivity, as fuel leaves the active core region. The molten fuel at the top of the core region may contact the cladding and cause fuel pin failure (as was observed during the TREAT M-Series tests). Although the figure depicts all bond sodium and non-gaseous radionuclides vaporizing due to the elevated temperatures before fuel pin failure (the middle diagram), some may stay in liquid form due to the very high internal pin pressures, then vaporize as pressure decreases following fuel pin failure. Once the cladding fails, the depressurization event is similar to what is predicted in pin failure without fuel melting, but with two significant differences. First, the internal pin pressure is likely higher than what is predicted in a non-melting event, due to the elevated temperatures. Second, molten fuel and solid fuel fragments can now be ejected from the fuel pin along with the fission gases and bond sodium. The ejected molten fuel will likely impact adjacent structure and may begin to freeze.
In terms of modeling the radionuclide release associated with fuel pin failure, there are three major questions that need resolved:
1) What radionuclides are released from the fuel pin?
2) What state are the radionuclides when they are released?
3) What radionuclides will be present in the bubble(s) formed in the coolant channel following release?

The first question, regarding which radionuclides are released from the fuel pin, is directly connected to the in-pin radionuclide migration discussed in Section 2.3. As described in that section, there is no computational tool available to assess radionuclide migration within the fuel pin, and the same is true regarding radionuclide release from the fuel pin. SAS4A/SASSYS-1 is capable of tracking fuel and fission gas movement from the fuel pin into the coolant channel, but it does not explicitly track fission products. Therefore, estimates must be developed based on available data and past accidents. A recent Argonne study (ANL-ART-38) performed this analysis, estimating the quantity of radionuclide release for metal fuel pin failures at various temperatures. This information is used as the basis for the radionuclide release estimates provided here.

The second and third questions are linked, and are equally difficult to assess. There is a large pressure change during fuel pin failure. Radionuclides that may have been in the solid or liquid phase before fuel pin failure may suddenly change states. Additionally, the violent blowdown of the fuel pin following failure likely causes the formation of aerosols and may impact the magnitude and rate of radionuclide vaporization. It is also difficult to estimate how many of these products will be present within the bubble formed in the coolant channel or which will be directly transported to the sodium coolant. A methodology was developed to attempt to account for these phenomena, while also providing bounds related to uncertainties.

The analysis of radionuclides release was split into three phases, as provided in Figure 2-11. First, the "pre-failure" assessment uses the commercial thermodynamic equilibrium computational tool HSC Chemistry 8 [19] to calculate the state of the radionuclides that are present within the bond sodium and fission gas plenum 11 , as shown in the region highlighted in Figure 2-12. HSC determines both the equilibrium chemical and physical state of the radionuclides based on the internal pin pressure and temperature. This calculation provides information regarding the initial conditions within the fuel pin.

During the "peri-failure" stage, HSC is again used to determine the state of radionuclides within the fuel pin. However, there are several differences from the previous stage. First, the pin pressure is now at the post-failure pressure, which is likely substantially lower than the pre-failure internal pin pressure. This increases the quantity of radionuclides that are vaporized and in the gas state. Second, additional radionuclides may have been liberated from the fuel matrix due to fuel melting (based on ANL-ART-38 analysis). These radionuclides are also included in the HSC calculation. Although HSC is an equilibrium code, and the "peri-failure" stage occurs quickly and is unlikely to establish thermodynamic equilibrium, the HSC results are considered conservative in terms of the formation of radionuclide gases. This assumption is based on the observation that vaporization requires a change in state that may be kinetically inhibited [20,21]. The final step of the analysis is the "postfailure" assessment. In this step, the goal is to determine what released radionuclides are present within the bubble(s) formed in the coolant channel. As will be discussed in Section 2.5, the initial radionuclide inventory within the bubble is important for determining the fraction of radionuclides transported to the cover gas region by bubble transport (and bypass of retention within the sodium pool).

The formation of the bubble represents very complex phenomena, and there is essentially no data available regarding the formation of radionuclide gas/aerosol bubbles within liquid sodium. Therefore, for the analysis here, two cases were considered that represent the extremes of the range of possible outcomes. In the first case, all radionuclides and bond sodium released from the fuel pin are assumed to be present within the bubble in either the gas/vapor state or as an aerosol. This assumption maximizes the initial radionuclide inventory within the bubble. In the second case, all released radionuclide gases/vapors are assumed to be within the bubble, but only 10% of the non-gaseous radionuclides and bond sodium are assumed to be within the bubble as aerosols. This was considered to be approximately the minimum quantity of non-gaseous radionuclides that could be present within the bubble initially.

div.head: Key Project Point
div.p: Due to uncertainties regarding the amount of the radionuclides released during fuel pin failure that become entrained in gas/vapor bubbles in the pool, two bounding cases were explored:
1) "All" of the non-gaseous radionuclides and bond sodium within the plenum become entrained in a bubble.
2) "10%" of the non-gaseous radionuclides and bond sodium in the plenum become entrained in a bubble.

div.head: PLOF+
div.p: The first calculation conducted for the PLOF+ transient was the pre-failure assessment of radionuclide forms within the fuel pin. This calculation is performed primarily for analyst's knowledge, and the results are not directly used in further analysis steps. An HSC calculation was conducted for each of the three fuel batches at temperatures and pressure immediately prior to fuel pin failure (utilizing the decayed pin inventory discussed in Section 2.3.2). Table 2-16 contains a list of these parameters for each fuel batch. These HSC calculations model those radionuclides within the fission gas plenum (and bond sodium in the fission gas plenum) and use the radionuclide inventories described in radionuclides. As mentioned previously, while it is known that conditions will not reach equilibrium during the fuel pin failure process, the HSC results are seen as bounding regarding the amount of gas/vapor creation. A summary of the calculation results can be found in Table 2-20, which shows much greater vaporization of Cs, Rb, and I than the pre-failure calculation. The determination of radionuclide release fractions from failed fuel pins was primarily based on the findings of ANL-ART-38. The release fractions are provided in Table 2-21, for each fuel pin region. As the table shows, the ANL-ART-38 analysis concluded that for fuel pin failure in this temperature range, radionuclide release would primarily be from the plenum region, with very little additional release from the fuel matrix. The only exceptions to this are the noble gases (Xe, Kr), where it is conservatively assumed that 100% of the noble gas pin inventory will be released, regardless of the burnup level. It is also conservatively assumed that all radionuclide releases occur instantly with failure of the fuel pin 13 . With the release fractions and radionuclide states established, it is now possible to begin the radionuclide bubble transport analysis, described in Section 2.5.

div.head: UTOP+
div.p: The UTOP+ calculation followed a process similar to that of the PLOF+. Only fuel batches B and C are examined here, since fuel batch A is assumed to remain intact during the transient. First, the pre-failure HSC calculation was performed for the temperatures and pressures shown in The peri-failure UTOP+ HSC calculation was conducted at the temperatures and pressures provided in Table 2-25. Since the primary pumps are still operational in the UTOP+ transient scenario, the coolant channel pressure is slightly higher than in the PLOF+ case, but considerably lower than the pre-failure internal pin pressures. A summary of the HSC peri-failure results can be found in Table 2-26. With depressurization, there is significant vaporization of many radionuclides, with very large percentages of Cs, Br, I, Rb, Ba, and Sr converting to the gas state. As will be described in Section 2.5, these fractions will be utilized to determine bubble behavior in the sodium pool. As for radionuclide release fractions for the UTOP+ transient, Table 2-27 contains the results of the calculation (based on ANL-ART-38 analyses), and provides the releases from both regions of the fuel pin.

For some radionuclides, such as the noble gases (Xe, Kr), Cs, Rb, and Eu, it was assumed that the remainder of the inventory present in the fuel matrix would volatize and escape the fuel pin. For the remaining elements, the calculation utilized the percent of the fuel matrix that had become molten during the transient (based on the TREAT experiments results, provided in Table 23456789). The molten fraction was multiplied by the ANL-ART-38 release fraction estimates for molten fuel for that element (or class of elements). As with the PLOF+ analysis, it is conservatively assumed that all radionuclide releases occur instantly with failure of the fuel pin.

div.head: Summary
div.p: There were three main classes of phenomena modeled during this phase of the MST trial calculation. First was the partitioning of radionuclides between the gas and liquid/solid phase while in the fuel pin plenum.

HSC was used to model this phenomena, which is based on thermodynamic equilibrium. It is possible that other phenomena, such as kinetics, plays a non-trivial role in partitioning between the gas and liquid/solid state, but there are essentially no available data to compare with the HSC results. Also, it is difficult to determine whether the results of the HSC calculation here are conservative or not, as they are inputs into further trial MST calculations steps.
Second, radionuclide release fractions from failed metal fuel pins to the primary sodium were estimated.

There is no computational tool capable of performing this task, but ANL-ART-38 developed radionuclide release estimates based on past data. There are partial gaps regarding this phenomenon, as described in greater detail in ANL-ART-38, and it is unclear whether the assumptions used to develop these release fractions are conservative in all cases.

Lastly, the timing of radionuclide release from failed fuel pins (meaning when radionuclides leave the fuel pin, not when the fuel pin fails) was not mechanistically treated, as no computational tool exists. Instead, all radionuclide releases were assumed to occur instantaneously with pin failure. This is a conservative assumption, as there will be a delay as some radionuclides migrate through the fuel pin to the cladding breach site. The instant release assumption maximizes the radionuclide inventory in radionuclide bubbles (maximizing bypass of the sodium pool) and maximizes the inventory within the sodium pool at a given moment, which increases the amount of vaporization to the cover gas region.

div.head: Radionuclide Bubble Transport
div.p: Following the analyses to determine the fraction of gases/vapors and aerosols that would be entrained in bubbles within the sodium pool (described in Section 2.4), which are released from the fuel pin subsequent to cladding breach, the scrubbing (or removal) of radionuclides from the bubbles during transport from the core region to the surface of the sodium pool was analyzed. This section provides details of the bubble scrubbing calculation, along with a brief description of the computational code utilized to perform the analysis.

div.head: Methodology
div.p: The transport of radionuclides through the sodium pool within bubbles involves a variety of phenomena, and the analysis of the transport mechanisms requires a variety of inputs from the transient scenario modeling and failed pin radionuclide release steps. Proper treatment of the blowdown process of gases/vapors and aerosols from failed fuel pins and their transport to the sodium pool surface within a bubble is important, as radionuclides may bypass the sodium pool, a major retention mechanism, and be directly released into the cover gas region, where subsequent transport may occur. While it is assumed that no retention of noble gases occurs in the sodium pool, significant retention of other radionuclides is likely.
It is therefore imperative to quantify the amount of radionuclide scrubbing (removal) that occurs from bubbles while passing through the sodium pool.

Figure 2-13 graphically depicts the processes that gases/vapors and aerosols undergo subsequent to fuel pin failure. Prior to fuel pin failure, the gases/vapors are assumed to be in the gas plenum of the fuel pin.

During the blowdown process these gases/vapors are released from the fuel pin and can push or carry bond sodium, along with radionuclides in the bond sodium, into the coolant channel. Some radionuclide aerosols may be entrained within the bubbles, while others may be directly released into the sodium pool. Some radionuclides within the bubbles may be removed before the bubble reaches the pool surface.

As shown in Table 2-29, there are many mechanisms which may remove aerosols from the bubbles, including: aerosol capture by Brownian diffusion, inertial deposition, and gravitational sedimentation; aerosol removal associated with vapor condensation; and thermophoresis and diffusiophoresis. Any radionuclides that are scrubbed from the bubbles are then deposited in the sodium pool, while the remaining radionuclides within the bubbles are released into the cover gas region once the bubble reaches the sodium pool surface (assuming the bubbles rupture at the surface). The radionuclides in the sodium pool may volatize and be released to the cover gas region. The radionuclide release due to volatilization is discussed in more detail in Section 2.6. To quantify the amount of radionuclide scrubbing that occurs during the travel through the sodium pool, a computational code developed during the IFR project was utilized [22]. This code will be referred to here as the IFR bubble code, as the code was never formally named or released. The IFR bubble code uses classical theories of aerosol scrubbing, which were developed for the case of isolated bubbles rising through water, with modifications to account for phenomena specific to a pool-type SFR. Additional modifications to the classical theories are incorporated to account for difference between a spherical bubble (for which the classical theories were developed) and ellipsoidal bubble, which are more likely to develop in liquid sodium.

As shown in Table 2-29, the IFR bubble code only considers aerosol capture by Brownian diffusion, inertial deposition, gravitational sedimentation, and the effects of sodium vapor condensation. Thermophoresis, diffusiophoresis, and the effects of vapor condensation of elements other than sodium on aerosol scrubbing are not currently considered in the code, however an attempt to model the effects of the vapor condensation of elements other than sodium was made through insights from additional HSC calculations. It is assumed that aerosol trapping occurs through particle deposition within isolated bubbles ascending through a sodium pool. Thus, detailed hydrodynamic phenomena such as jet (or plume) flow, bubble agglomeration, bubble shattering, bubble swarms, etc. are not addressed. The models in the code assume a bubbly flow regime (i.e., isolated bubbles ascending through a sodium pool with a wellcharacterized terminal rise velocity), where the initial bubble size is limited by hydrodynamic instability. The output of the code is a decontamination factor (DF) for each of the four scrubbing mechanisms (Brownian diffusion, inertial deposition, gravitational sedimentation, and condensation), through which aerosols are removed from the bubbles. Multiplying these four DFs together provides the overall total DF. The IFR bubble code has only been validated against bubble behavior in water, not liquid sodium.

Table 2-30 provides a list of the required input parameters for the IFR bubble code. The values for sodium pool depth, sodium pool temperature, cover gas pressure, inlet gas temperature, and inlet gas pressure were derived from the results from SAS4A/SASSYS-1 simulations of the two transient scenarios (PLOF+ and UTOP+). The aerosol particle density and diameter were assumed to be constants for the analysis provided described here. The impact of this assumption is discussed in greater detail in the following two subsections. The inlet gas vapor content was determined from the HSC calculations described in Section 2.4.

div.head: PLOF+
div.p: In the PLOF+ transient scenario, the results from the SAS4A/SASSYS-1 analysis (discussed in Section 2.2.2) were used to determine the input values for the inlet gas temperature, inlet gas pressure, pool temperature, and pool depth for the IFR bubble code. The results of the HSC calculations described in Section 2.4.2 were used to define the mole fraction of each element listed in Table 2-31. A separate bubble scrubbing analysis was conducted for each of the three fuel batches. The expected bubble diameter for each fuel batch was calculated based on hydrodynamic instability [23]. The density of the aerosol particles was assumed to be equal to that of CsI and the diameter of the aerosol particles were assumed to be 0.1 µm. These assumptions are discussed later in this section. The IFR bubble code results for the three fuel batches are shown in Table 2-32. The overall DFs for the PLOF+ transient are relatively small due to several factors. First, the pool temperatures at the time of fuel pin failure are not significantly lower than the inlet gas temperatures. Therefore, very little sodium condensation occurs (which is evident in the condensation DF being approximately unity). The assumed small aerosol diameter (0.1 µm) results in both the inertial deposition DF and the gravitational DF being approximately unity. No data was available to approximate the diameter of the aerosol particles, which has a significant impact of the overall DF. Also, a single aerosol particle density was assumed (4,510 kg/m 3 ) instead of performing a calculation for each major species in Table 2-18. Instead, a sensitivity study was performed to demonstrate the effects of aerosol diameter and density on the total DF.

The results of the sensitivity study are provided in Figure 2-14 for fuel batch C. It is important to note that the total DF is not dependent on aerosol particle densities for values less than approximately 0.03 µm 15 . In this region, Brownian diffusion is dominant, whereas inertial deposition and gravitational sedimentation become a greater factor at aerosol particle diameters above 0.03 µm. The results of the sensitivity study demonstrate the importance of aerosol particle diameter and density on the total DF. The values assumed for these parameters in the PLOF+ scenario are in the region where the total DF is near a minimum value. This provides a conservative, but perhaps unrealistic, value for the total DF. However, as no data were available to approximate expected aerosol particle diameters (or densities), conservative values were utilized. It is possible to perform additional IFR bubble code calculations using the densities of the major species identified in Table 2-18, but this calculation was not performed for the current study, as the uncertainty regarding aerosol diameter would still have a significant effect.

div.head: UTOP+
div.p: As with the PLOF+ transient, the IFR bubble code inputs for the UTOP+ scenario (provided in The overall DFs of the UTOP+ scenario are significantly higher than those of the PLOF+ transient. The largest DF for both fuel batches was the condensation DF. In this scenario, the inlet gas temperatures are much higher (1300°C and 1229°C) than the bulk sodium pool temperature (515°C). At these elevated temperatures, a significant fraction of the bond sodium in the pin is gaseous prior to pin failure, and condenses once it is released from the pin into the sodium pool. Because of the large difference in inlet gas temperatures and sodium pool temperatures, an additional HSC calculation was performed to determine the amount of other gaseous species (in addition the sodium vapor) that would condense while the bubble traveled through the sodium pool. These results indicated significant condensation of cesium vapor. This additional condensation is reflected in the condensation DFs provided in Table 2-34.

As with the PLOF+ calculation, the assumed small aerosol diameter (0.1 µm) results in both the inertial deposition DF and the gravitational DF being approximately unity. A sensitivity study was performed with the UTOP+ results (fuel batch B) to demonstrate the effects of aerosol diameter and density on the total DF. The results of the sensitivity study are provided in Figure 2-15 for fuel batch B. The total DF for the UTOP+ scenario is higher than the PLOF+ for all aerosol densities. This is due to the condensation DF, which dominates in this scenario for all aerosol particle diameters and densities (as the condensation DF does not depend on either of these two parameters in the IFR bubble code). It is important to note that the total DF is not dependent on aerosol particle densities for values less than approximately 0.03 µm 16 for the same reasons stated in the PLOF+ scenario. The results of the sensitivity study for the UTOP+ scenario demonstrate the importance of aerosol particle diameter and density on the total DF.

div.head: Summary
div.p: The assessment of radionuclide transport in, and subsequent removal from, bubbles within the sodium pool includes many different phenomena, as shown in Table 2-35. The first step of the analysis was the determination of what radionuclides to include within the bubbles. As described in Section 2.4, no computational tool currently exists to evaluate this phenomenon, but it is very important to subsequent radionuclide release to the cover gas region. Therefore, two bounding cases ("all" and "10%" in bubble) were assessed to evaluate the impact on the final offsite release.

Next, there are several bubble and aerosol characteristics that impact the magnitude of radionuclide scrubbing that occurs when the bubble passes through the sodium pool. First, the bubble diameter was assumed to be limited by hydrostatic pressure, which is likely a conservative assumption, as smaller bubbles would aid in radionuclide removal. Second, the particle size of the aerosols was assumed to be 0.1 µm, with a density of 4,510 kg/m 3 . As with the bubble diameter, these are likely conservative assumptions, as they result in radionuclide scrubbing levels near the minimum of the possible range (as shown in Figure 2-14 and Figure 2-15). Finally, the actual removal of radionuclides from the bubbles within the sodium pool was modeled using a code developed during the IFR project. The code includes many, but not all, of the relevant phenomena that impact radionuclide removal. Also, the code has not been validated against experimentation with regard to bubble behavior in sodium.

div.head: HSC and Sensitivity Analysis Yes -It is not known what radionuclides released from the failed fuel pins will become entrained in bubbles.
div.p: As a major source of uncertainty, the MST trial calculation used two bounding cases to quantitatively assess the impact of the phenomena on the MST trial calculation.

div.head: Bubble diameter Not Modeled -Diameter calculated based on hydrostatic instability
div.p: Yes -Data on bubble creation in sodium following the blowdown of a metal fuel pin is not available. Without data to estimate the bubble size distribution, it is difficult to know if hydrostatic instability is the appropriate method for estimating the expected bubble diameter.

div.head: Conservative (Probable) -
div.p: The diameter of the bubble has a significant effect on the total decontamination factor. Smaller bubbles would greatly increase the decontamination factor. The hydrostatic instability limit calculation results in larger bubble diameters, which minimizes the decontamination factor.

div.head: Not Modeled -Single value assumed
div.p: Yes -A computational tool (and sufficient experimental data) does not exist to adequately assess the size of aerosol particles in the bubble.

div.head: Conservative (Probable) -
div.p: The assumption of a single aerosol particle diameter, resulting in the total DF near its minimum value, likely under predicts the amount of aerosol scrubbing that would occur.

div.head: Not Modeled -Single value assumed
div.p: Partial -The densities of each species of aerosol could be modeled separately. However, this density is expected to change with temperature and pressure, which vary significantly between the fuel pin prior to failure and sodium pool environment.

div.head: Conservative (Probable) -
div.p: The assumption of a single aerosol particle density results in the under-prediction of the total DF for denser particles (U, Am, Pu), many of which are important contributors to offsite dose.

div.head: Scrubbing of vapors and aerosols in radionuclide bubble passing through sodium pool (phenomena in Table 2-29)
IFR Bubble Code Partial -The IFR bubble code has only been validated against waterbased experiments, not sodium experiments, and does not include all pertinent removal phenomena.
div.p: Unclear -Without sodium experiments for comparison, it is unclear whether the results of the IFR bubble code are conservative or optimistic.

div.head: Sodium Pool Radionuclide Release
div.p: This subsection assesses the release of radionuclides from the sodium pool into the cover gas region, including the results of bubble transport analysis, described in the preceding section.

div.head: Methodology
div.p: The determination of radionuclide release from the sodium pool to the cover gas region is a complex analysis utilizing the results from three previous calculation steps. There are several pathways in which radionuclides can be transported from the sodium pool to the cover gas. First, as described in the previous section, radionuclides can bypass the pool entirely through transport in a gas bubble. Second, radionuclides within the sodium pool may vaporize to the cover gas region. Lastly, radionuclides may be transported due to other phenomena, such as mechanical forces when bubbles burst at the pool surface, or due to liftoff from cover gas circulation. The first method, gas bubble transport, has already been described. This section focuses on the latter transport methods, but the final releases sum amongst all modeled transport mechanisms.

As shown in Table 2-36, there are a variety of phenomena that influence the transport of radionuclides from the sodium pool to the cover gas region. These include several factors that could result in retention of radionuclides within the pool (plate-out, settling), and others that could increase or retard vaporization from the pool (non-homogenous mixing, localized oxidation). The remainder of this subsection describes the computational tool used to assess transport to the cover gas region, including the assumptions used to address the various phenomena. Radionuclide vaporization from the pool was quantified using fundamental thermodynamic relationships, which were implemented using HSC Chemistry 8. A custom thermodynamic database, compiled for this project, was used to determine the equilibrium distribution of key chemical species (e.g., Cs, I, NaI, CsI) between gas, liquid and solid phases for each step in the transient scenarios. The custom thermodynamic database and the thermodynamic basis for the HSC chemical modeling is presented in Appendix C of this report.

This modeling approach is mechanistic in that it quantifies the thermodynamic driving force responsible for the release of radionuclides from the liquid sodium coolant into the cover gas. Specifically, the model quantifies the equilibrium vapor pressures of radionuclides at a specified pressure, temperature and bulk composition. The vapor pressures are quantified in HSC using a variation of the Redlich-Kwong equation of state and a standard Gibbs free energy minimization algorithm that calls a thermodynamic database populated with species-specific standard values for enthalpy, entropy, and heat capacities [19]. The Gibbs free energy minimization is achieved by a standard Lagrangian-multiplier numerical method. To account for the non-ideality of the fission product/actinide/sodium pool mixture, thermodynamic mixing functions were derived from literature sources and are quantified in the HSC Chemistry model as species-specific activity coefficients.
