The derivation of the excess functions and activity coefficients is discussed in Appendix C. Also, an oxygen content of five parts per million was assumed within the sodium pool, which is typically an upper-bound on reactor grade sodium oxygen content [24]. For the PLOF+ and UTOP+ analyses, radionuclides are assumed to remain within the hot pool of the primary sodium circuit, as shown in Figure 2-16. This is considered a conservative assumption, especially for the UTOP+ transient, as primary system flow may disperse radionuclides throughout the system.

In addition to the thermodynamic mechanism of equilibrium vaporization, kinetic factors may play an important role in the release of radionuclides from the pool to the cover gas. The kinetics of release are influenced by the coolant fluid dynamics, liquid surface area, and other scenario-specific factors. Since many of these kinetic influences are poorly quantified, or are unknown for a particular transient scenario, the chemical model used in this study is does not account for specific kinetic processes other than physical bubble transport, as discussed in Section 2.5. The model is therefore likely conservative with respect to kinetic factors in that it is assumed that the radionuclide equilibrium vapor pressures are achieved instantaneously. Specific kinetic and other non-equilibrium processes that could occur at the sodium pool surface, but are not accounted for in the HSC chemical model are:
• Non-homogenous radionuclide mixing in the sodium pool.

• Plate-out (adsorption) and settling of radionuclides within the sodium pool, and condensation or precipitation of volatilized fission products onto cooler steel surfaces of the cover-gas region (the latter is taken into account in the cover gas region analysis in Section 2.7).
• Localized oxidation at the pool liquid/gas interface due to oxygen impurities.
• Spraying due to turbulence (or bubble pop) followed by gas transport by convection.

First, non-homogenous mixing of radionuclides in the sodium pool may occur. This could result in radionuclides concentrating near the cover gas region/sodium pool boundary (or other locations). There is some experimental evidence that indicates cesium and NaI may concentrate near the gas-liquid boundary [25,26]. However, there is insufficient experimental information to attempt to model this phenomenon. Therefore, perfect mixing within the hot pool is assumed. Second, plate-out (adsorption) and settling of radionuclides in the sodium pool is not taken into account, although evidence from past accidents and experiments exists indicating that it could occur [5]. However, the available data does not explicitly indicate the temperature or flow conditions at which radionuclide removal would transpire. Condensation or precipitation processes within the cover gas region are not considered here, but these phenomena are discussed in further detail in the cover gas region analysis in Section 2.7.

Localized oxidation at the pool/cover gas interface due to oxygen impurities would tend to slow the volatilization of radionuclides from the pool by forming a thin film of ordered, oxygen bonded species at the pool surface. It is conceivable that some solid radionuclide oxides could be transported, as fine particulate, by gas convection into the cover gas region; however, this process has not been observed experimentally [27,28].

The spraying phenomenon requires turbulence within the sodium pool and could conceivably be a source of radionuclide bearing-aerosols under highly turbulent conditions, such as boiling, or a bubble swarm reaching the pool surface. The transients assessed in the trial MST calculation do not experience sodium boiling in the primary sodium. Additional releases from gas bubbles popping at the pool surface could occur, but no data was found regarding the possible aerosol formation following this event.

div.head: PLOF+
div.p: Radionuclide release from the sodium pool to the cover gas region was particularly challenging for the PLOF+ transient scenario. This is due to the extended transient period, multiple fuel pin failure events, and the very high primary system temperatures. Figure 2-17 provides a graphical overview of the analysis procedure. As the figure shows, the transient begins at time zero, with reactor shutdown occurring shortly thereafter. From there, the radionuclide inventory in each fuel pin begins to decay (as was accounted for when determining the inventory in Section 2.3.2). At 22.65 hours into the transient, fuel Batch C fails, releasing radionuclides to the primary sodium. Some radionuclides enter the bubbles, while others directly enter the sodium pool. As the bubbles rise through the sodium pool, bubble scrubbing removes some radionuclides, which then become part of the pool radionuclide inventory. Using this combined inventory (those radionuclides directly released, and those from bubble scrubbing), a vaporization calculation is performed. Those radionuclides that remain in the sodium pool then decay until the next fuel batch failure. At 28.98 hours into the transient, Batch B fuel pins fail. As with Batch C failure, some radionuclides enter bubbles, while others directly enter the pool, where they join the remains of the Batch C radionuclide release. Following additional bubble scrubbing, another vaporization calculation is performed, followed by the decay of those radionuclides still in the sodium pool. This process is repeated one additional time at 31.89 hours, when fuel Batch A fails.

As described in Section 2.4.1, two different radionuclide bubble cases were considered. In the first case, all radionuclides in the plenum region and bond sodium are assumed to become aerosols within the bubbles. The results of this case are shown in Figure 2-18, for selected elements (complete results can be found in Appendix A.3). In the figure, the radionuclide release to the cover gas is split into six phases, to align with the releases shown in Figure 2-17. As can be seen, vaporization from the sodium pool is essentially negligible when compared to the quantity of radionuclides transported within the bubbles. Only cesium vaporization amounts to greater than one gram of transport. However, due to the large radionuclide inventories in the bubbles (and the very small bubble scrubbing factor, described in Section 2.5.2), very large amounts of cesium are transported to the cover gas region. In addition, heavier elements, such as americium, are also transported to the cover gas region. This is a direct result of the assumptions regarding the amount of these radionuclides in the bond sodium within the plenum prior to fuel pin failure, and the assumption regarding the amount of the bond sodium that becomes entrained within the bubbles following fuel pin failure. Figure 2-19 shows the same results for the "10% in bubble" case. As the figure shows, the release of radionuclides to the cover gas region are essentially reduced by an order of magnitude (other than the noble gases, which are not affected by the 10% assumption). Vaporization from the pool increases slightly, as the inventory in the pool is greater in this case than the "all in bubble" case. However, pool vaporization is still negligible compared to radionuclide transport within the bubbles. One additional HSC pool vaporization calculation was performed to examine the influence of the increase in pool temperatures after the failure of Batch A fuel. As Figure 2-5 showed, Batch A fuel failed when primary sodium temperatures were at 661°C. This is the temperature used for the "Batch A Vap" calculation results presented above. However, the sodium pool continues to increase in temperature, until it achieves a maximum of ~850°C. The higher temperature would likely increase the magnitude of radionuclide vaporization. The HSC calculation performed at 661°C was repeated at 850°C. While an increase in vaporization was seen, the change in the total radionuclide release to the cover gas was negligible 18 . Specifically, the amount of iodine vaporized increased by approximately an order of magnitude, while the amount of cesium vaporized increased by slightly more than double. As Figure 2-18 and Figure 2-19 show, the amount of radionuclide transport from the bubbles still dominates the increased vaporization levels.

div.head: UTOP+
div.p: The UTOP+ analysis of radionuclide releases to the cover gas region was more straightforward than the PLOF+ scenario. Fuel batches B and C fail at the same time, with no time for radionuclide decay before release. Therefore, bubble transport from fuel batches B and C occurs simultaneously, and only a single vaporization event occurs (as with the PLOF+ scenario, vaporization is assumed to occur instantaneously).

Figure 2-20 provides the cover gas radionuclide release results for the "all in bubble" case, for selected elements (complete results can be found in Appendix A.3). As with the PLOF+ scenario, vaporization from the pool is essentially negligible compared to transport in bubbles. Since far fewer pins fail during the UTOP+ scenario, when compared to the PLOF+ transient, the releases to the cover gas are generally smaller. The lower temperature of the hot pool also aids in bubble scrubbing, reducing releases to the cover gas from bubbles even further. Figure 2-21 has similar results for the "10% in bubble" case. Again, releases are reduced by approximately an order of magnitude, and the increase in vaporization from the pool does not become a major factor.

div.head: Summary
div.p: The release of radionuclides from the sodium pool to the cover gas region involves many phenomena, as shown in Table 2-37. The first phenomenon (vaporization from the pool, including thermodynamic effects) was directly addressed using HSC. However, the available database is limited, and required significant analyst effort to compile. The specific timing of radionuclide vaporization was not modeled. Instead, a conservative assumption of instant vaporization was used. Several phenomena were ignored, such as kinetic effects, plate-out, and mechanical forces, as no computational tools exist to address these. This results in both conservative and non-conservative impacts. Lastly, perfect mixing was also assumed, which is likely non-conservative, but radionuclides were assumed to remain within the hot pool, which increases vaporization.

div.head: Timing of Vaporization Not Modeled -Instant release assumed
div.p: Yes -A computational tool (and sufficient experimental data) does not exist to capture time effects of radionuclide vaporization.
Conservative -The assumption of instant vaporization is conservative, as it minimized the time for radioactive decay, and maximized cover gas region inventory.

div.head: Kinetic Effects No Computational Tool Exists -Not modeled
div.p: Yes -A computational tool (and associated experimental data) to determine kinetic effects within the sodium pool does not exist.

div.head: Conservative (probable) -Kinetic effects would likely decrease the rate of vaporization
div.p: to the cover gas region, and instant equilibrium vapor pressures are assumed.

div.head: No Computational Tool Exists -Perfect mixing assumed (in hot pool)
div.p: Yes -Although there is some experimental evidence that indicates that non-homogenous radionuclide mixing may occur, the data are insufficient to model the phenomena.
Non-conservative -Nonhomogenous mixing could result in radionuclide concentration at the gas/liquid boundary, increasing vaporization.

div.head: Plate-out (Adsorption) and Settling in Sodium Pool
No Computational Tool Exists -Not modeled
div.p: Yes -Due to a lack of temperature-and flow-dependent information, radionuclide losses in the pool due to adsorption and settling were ignored.

div.head: Conservative -Ignoring radionuclide losses in the pool increases the radionuclide inventory available for vaporization.
Mechanical Forces (Liftoff due to Bubble Pop, Turbulence, or Convection)
No Computational Tool Exists -Not modeled
div.p: Yes -Due to a lack of data regarding aerosol formation due to turbulence and bubble pop, this phenomenon was ignored.
Non-conservative -Radionuclide releases from the sodium pool to the cover gas would be in addition to the releases from vaporization.

div.head: Cover Gas Region Analysis
div.p: The original analysis procedure, as outlined in the project work plan [29], was to utilize a developmental version of CONTAIN-LMR for the assessment of radionuclide transport/retention in the cover gas region and containment. However, due to complications with the implementation of CONTAIN-LMR, detailed results were not available by the end of the current study. The issues encountered with CONTAIN-LMR are discussed further in this section and in Appendix A.4. To allow for the completion of the trial MST calculation within the project timeframe constraints, a simplified radionuclide transport code (referenced here as the SRT code) was developed that utilizes general assumptions to address radionuclide transport phenomena. The following subsection describes the analysis methodology and the capabilities of the SRT code. This is followed by the results of the cover gas region analysis for both the PLOF+ and UTOP+ transient scenarios.

div.head: Methodology
div.p: The assessment of radionuclide behavior in the cover gas region utilizes the outputs of the bubble transport and sodium pool release analysis steps. Also, outputs from the transient scenario modeling are necessary to establish temperatures and pressures within the cover gas region. Radionuclides that enter the cover gas region may experience a variety of phenomena, as shown in Table 2-38. If there is a reduction in temperatures, radionuclide vapors could condense. Heavier aerosols may settle due to gravitational forces, and smaller aerosols may agglomerate and also settle. Due to the inert (argon) atmosphere of the cover gas region, there are no interactions between the radionuclides and the cover gas, although interactions between the radionuclides themselves and with the sodium vapor are possible.

Radionuclide transport from the cover gas region to containment is most likely a result of leakage from seals around reactor head penetrations. The leakage area is expected to be both temperature-and pressuredependent, due to the different types of seals used for reactor head penetrations. For example, elastomer seals leak primarily due to permeability, which is temperature dependent, while mechanical seals primary leak due to pressure differentials, such as that between the cover gas region and containment.

div.head: CONTAIN-LMR
div.p: The initial project plan was to utilize a developmental version of CONTAIN-LMR [30] to model radionuclide behavior within the cover gas region (and containment). CONTAIN-LMR is a liquid metal reactor version of CONTAIN version 1.11 [31], developed in the late 1980s and early 1990s by SNL. However, SNL terminated formal support of the code soon thereafter, and many versions of the code, modified by third parties, now exist. A current project at SNL is transferring the sodium-specific modeling aspects of CONTAIN-LMR into MELCOR [32], which is currently supported by SNL. However, this project was not yet completed at the time of the current work 19 , which resulted in the decision to utilize a developmental version of CONTAIN-LMR directly.
As discussed in greater detail in Appendix A.4, several issues soon arose regarding the capabilities of the available version of CONTAIN-LMR, including:
• Inability to model noble gases as gases, rather than aerosols • Limitation of eight aerosol chemical classes (including a class dedicated to sodium aerosols)

• Limitations in the treatment of pressure-dependent control volume leakage pathways • Limitations in the treatment of heat structures and heat transfer pathways • Code instability, resulting in subsequent changes to the source code Modeling simplifications and gross assumptions were necessary to address these shortcomings within CONTAIN-LMR simulations. Taken together, these modeling choices resulted in unrealistic CONTAIN-LMR results. Although source code modifications were made to address several of these issues, the revised version of CONTAIN-LMR was not available before the completion of the current project. Therefore, the decision was made to use a surrogate, simplified computer code to address radionuclide transport in the cover gas region and containment, in order to allow the completion of the trial MST calculation 20 .

div.head: Simplified Radionuclide Transport (SRT) Code
div.p: Due to the difficulties encountered while implementing models in CONTAIN-LMR, and the condensed timeline of the project, a simplified radionuclide transport code (referenced here as the SRT code for brevity) was developed to allow for analyses of transport/retention phenomena in the cover gas region and containment. The purpose of the code was to allow rapid evaluations of radionuclide transport/retention phenomena, based on simplified assumptions.

The SRT code was developed by Argonne, and is a time-based analysis tool. The SRT code is essentially a zero-D tool that considers three control volumes (the cover gas region, containment, and the environment), with perfect mixing in each volume, as shown in the schematic in Figure 2-22. Flow paths, with user designated leakage rates, are included from the cover gas region to the containment, and from containment to the environment. Although simple, the SRT code permits an approximation of radionuclide movement from the cover gas region to the containment and environment, while accounting for major impacting factors. The SRT code tracks all (>700) radionuclide isotopes, and assesses radionuclide transport/retention phenomena based on assumptions that the user can modify, such as:

• Radionuclide Decay and Daughters -The decay of radionuclides within the cover gas region and containment is included in the calculation, but daughter products are only included for the noble gases. • Aerosol Deposition -Aerosol deposition is assessed using an exponential decay function. All airborne radionuclides (other than the noble gases) are assumed to be in aerosol form, and deposit according to the same decay constant. However, different decay constants can be specified for the cover gas region and containment. No resuspension is assumed. • Leakage -Leakage from the cover gas region into containment, and from containment to the environment, is calculated based on user-specified leakage rates.

Radionuclide decay is included for all isotopes while they are in the cover gas region and containment, with daughter products included for the noble gas isotopes with relatively short half-lives (<5 days). Aerosol deposition is treated through the use of an exponential decay function. All radionuclides, other than the noble gases, are assumed to be in the aerosol form when in the cover gas region or containment (vapors are assumed to either condense to form aerosols or to react and transport with aerosols). A single decay constant is applied to all aerosol radionuclides, although separate decay constants can be used in the cover gas region and containment (a decay constant of 1.1E-4 per second was chosen for the cover gas region, and Appendix A.4 has further discussion on the selection of decay constants for the aerosol calculation, which included an assessment of past experiments and analyses). There is no resuspension of aerosols once they have deposited, and no limits are placed on the amount of aerosol deposition that can occur.

Leakage from the cover gas region to containment, and from containment to the environment, is based on a user-specified leakage rate. This is a simplifying assumption, as leakage will likely be both pressure-and temperature-dependent. Since the reference reactor lacks the detailed seal arrangement design necessary to determine actual temperature-and pressure-dependent leak rates, two bounding values were used to assess this uncertainty. First, a leakage rate of 10.4 cm 3 per second was used, based on information from the Fast Flux Test Facility (FFTF) [34]. This translates into a leakage rate of approximately 0.55 volume percent per day. Second, an upper bound value of 1000 cm 3 per second was used, to simulate a degraded reactor head condition, possible from the failure of a large seal or piping interface. This value translates into a leakage rate of 52 volume percent per day 21 .

As described in preceding sections, both isotopic composition and chemical forms were assessed during the analysis of radionuclide release to the cover gas. However, as shown in Figure 2-23, the SRT code does not take into account chemical species (such as CsI or NaI). Furthermore, as will be discussed in Section 2.9, with the computational tool used for offsite dispersion calculations (WinMACCS), individual isotopes, without regards to their host chemical form, are assessed. Perhaps the biggest shortcoming of the SRT code is the inability to model chemical interactions between sodium vapor/aerosols and oxygen. Since this interaction is of minimal concern for the cover gas analysis, as argon is used within the region, further discussion will be provided in Section 2.8, which details the containment analysis.

For both the PLOF+ and UTOP+ scenarios, the SRT calculation assessed the transport and release of radionuclides over the first seven days (168 hours) of the incident. This extend analysis period requires certain assumptions regarding the transient scenarios and follow-up response. For example, the analysis takes no credit for actions to reduce leakage from the reactor vessel to containment or from the containment to the environment, including efforts to reduce system temperatures or pressures. These are conservative assumptions that result in additional releases to the environment.

div.head: PLOF+
div.p: Four sets of results are presented for the PLOF+ scenario, as shown in Table 2-39, as both the "all" and "10%" bubble cases (described in Section 2.4) are assessed with both small (0.55 vol%/day) and large (52.0 vol%/day) leakage pathways from the reactor head to the containment. Detailed results are only presented here for the case numbers 2 and 4, as cases 1 and 3 are very similar, but with non-noble gas inventory reductions of approximately an order of magnitude due to the bubble transport assumptions. Figure 2-24 shows the inventory of selected radionuclides within the cover gas region during the 7-day period. The figure shows the total inventory within the cover gas region, and the quantity removed due to decay, deposition, and leakage for each time step (1 hour). The radionuclides were chosen to illustrate the behavior of different radionuclide groups. Three radionuclide releases to the cover gas occur, at 22.65, 28.98, and 31.89 hours (the radionuclide release due to bubble transport and vaporization at those times is combined to create a single release). The calculation was performed for 168 hours (7 days) following the initial fuel pin failures, for a total analysis time of 191 hours.

As Figure 2-24 illustrates, there is very little radionuclide removal from radioactive decay, as fuel failure begins to occur at over 22 hours after the reactor has shutdown. Therefore, many of the short-lived radionuclides decayed while still within the fuel pin (and their daughter products were accounted for in the analysis conducted in Section 2.3.2). Additionally, no deposition of the noble gases occurs, and their movement to the containment is only a function of the reactor head leakage rate and removal from radioactive decay. For the non-noble gases, aerosol deposition is a major factor, dramatically reducing radionuclide inventories within the cover gas region during the days immediately following fuel pin failure. The reduction in airborne radionuclides due to deposition appears as a straight line on the log plot due to the use of an exponential decay function. In actuality, aerosol removal due to deposition may reach a lower limit, where the concentration of airborne radionuclides is stable, with little additional deposition. However, no lower limit is applied to the calculation results shown here. Due to this assumption, radionuclide transport to the containment for non-noble gases becomes essentially negligible prior to 100 hours after the initiation of the transient.

The fraction of the total core inventory released into containment for all radionuclides of interest is shown in Figure 2-25. The biggest release fractions are for the noble gases, as a large percentage was released from the failed fuel pins, and there is no removal pathway in the sodium pool or cover gas other than radioactive decay. The difference in fuel pin release fractions and radioactive decay accounts for the majority of the difference between the release fractions for the elements in the table.

The results for PLOF+ case 4 are shown in Figure 2-26, where the leakage into containment is two orders of magnitude greater than in case 2. As the figure shows, due to the increased leakage, transport to containment becomes the largest removal mechanism of noble gases in the cover gas region (greater than radioactive decay). However, deposition is still the primary removal pathway for radionuclide aerosols.

Complete results are shown in Figure 2-27. As shown in the table, the fraction released into containment is not always directly scalable from case 2, even though the only difference is the leakage rate from the cover gas region into containment. Due to the increased leakage, some radionuclides transport to the containment before they decay in the cover gas region. Therefore, the total transport of radionuclides to containment may be greater than the change in leakage rate between cases 2 and 4 for radionuclides with relative short half-lives. As with case 2, due to aerosol deposition, radionuclide transport to the containment becomes essentially negligible for all radionuclides other than the noble gases within about 100 hours from the onset of the transient.

div.head: UTOP+
div.p: The same cases shown in Table 2-39 were also assessed for the UTOP+ scenario. Figure 2-28 shows the inventory of selected radionuclides within the cover gas region during the 7-day period. All radionuclide releases to the cover gas are assumed to occur at time zero, due to the rapid nature of the transient. Unlike the PLOF+ scenario, radioactive decay is major factor in reducing radionuclide inventories initially, as the fuel pin failures occurred while the reactor was still at power. However, aerosol deposition soon becomes the dominant radionuclide removal pathway several hours after the initial release. By 50 hours after the initiation of the transient, the transport of radionuclides to the containment is essentially negligible for all elements but the noble gases.

The complete list of release fractions to the containment over the 7 day analysis period is shown in Figure 2-29. In general, these fractions are far below those seen in the PLOF+ transient, as far fewer assemblies in the core experienced fuel pin failure. However, the release of krypton and xenon is fairly close to that seen in case 2 of the PLOF+ transient, as the reduced decay time of the UTOP+ transient results in a large inventory of the noble gases, even though far fewer fuel pins failed in the UTOP+ scenario. , where again, the leakage rate to the containment is increased by approximately two orders of magnitude. Here, the impact of reduced decay time of the noble gases results is a release of over 1% of the core inventory of xenon into the containment. For all non-noble gas radionuclides, the releases to containment increase by approximately the same amount as the increase in cover gas leakage rate.
Activity (Ci)

div.head: Summary
div.p: The analysis of radionuclide behavior within the cover gas region is very complex, and involves many phenomena, as shown in Table 2-40. The assessment of modeling gaps is particularly challenging for the cover gas region and containment analyses, as the SRT code was utilized for the analysis described here, but a version of MELCOR with the addition of sodium-specific models will soon be available. Therefore, Table 2-40 discusses the modeling approaches utilized for the current analysis, but also includes capabilities that will be included in the new version of MELCOR when discussing gaps.

SAS4A/SASSYS-1 provides cover gas temperature and pressure. However, SAS4A/SASSYS-1 does not account for heat transfer to the containment or other reactor building structure. The SRT code does not account for these phenomena, since it conservatively uses a constant leakage rate to containment (not temperature-or pressure-dependent). However, such heat transfer capabilities will be available in the new version of MELCOR.

The SRT code accounts for radioactive decay while radionuclides are within the cover gas region and containment, but daughter products are only included for the short-lived noble gases. This is considered a partial gap, as daughter products are typically not included within MELCOR calculations.

There are several phenomena that are not addressed in the SRT code, but that will be modeled in the new version of MELCOR. These include the condensation of sodium vapor, resuspension and re-vaporization, and chemical interactions between radionuclides. The SRT code addresses aerosol deposition through the use of a single exponential decay constant. MELCOR allows class-dependent deposition properties.

Neither the SRT code or MELCOR can address aerosol deposition in flow paths, which is likely conservative, as deposition would not only remove airborne aerosols, but also restrict the flow area over time.

div.head: Non-conservative -Resuspension and vaporization would increase the amount of airborne radionuclides.
Not modeled Yes -Neither the SRT code of MELCOR models the deposition of aerosol in flow paths.
div.p: Conservative -Radionuclides that would otherwise deposit in a flowpath (such as a leakage pathway from the reactor head) will be available for release to the containment, and the flow path is not reduced due to plugging.

div.head: Not modeled
div.p: No (MELCOR) -The SRT code did not assess chemical interaction of radionuclide vapors with aerosols. However, to some extent MELCOR will be able to address these interactions.
Unclear -The cumulative impact of chemical interactions on the transport of radionuclides in the cover gas region is unclear.

div.head: Seal Leakage Sensitivity Analysis
div.p: Partial -MELCOR is capable of modeling temperature-and pressure-dependent leakage, but sufficient data are needed to estimate leakage functions.
Due to the lack of a detailed reactor design, two values (0.55% vol/day and 52.0% vol/day) were used to assess radionuclide leakage from the cover gas region to containment.

div.head: Containment Region Analysis
div.p: The containment region analysis, like the cover gas region analysis, was to originally be assessed using CONTAIN-LMR. However, this part of the analysis was also conducted with the SRT code, due to difficulties encountered with CONTAIN-LMR. The following subsections describe the containmentspecific aspects of the modeling methodology, along with the results for the PLOF+ and UTOP+ scenarios.

div.head: Methodology
div.p: The analysis of radionuclide behavior in the containment requires only the results from the cover gas region analysis 22 . The radionuclide transport/retention phenomena encountered during this analysis step are almost identical to that of the cover gas region analysis. However, radionuclides entering the containment now have an opportunity to interact with water vapor and oxygen in the air. Also, containment leakage phenomena are different than that of seal leakage from the reactor head. As with the analysis of the cover gas region, the SRT code was utilized to assess radionuclide transport and retention within the containment. A single node, with perfect mixing, was used to model the containment atmosphere, which is potentially conservative given the size of the reference reactor containment, as perfect mixing will result in the initiation of leakage to the environment immediately following the introduction of radionuclides to the containment. The most significant drawback of using the SRT code for the assessment of the containment is the lack of chemical interaction modeling in the code, particularly sodium/oxygen reactions, which has several repercussions for the analysis:

• Sodium vapor/aerosol interactions with oxygen in the containment would likely result in the formation of larger sodium oxide aerosols. Airborne radionuclides may deposit on these aerosols, and settle due to gravitational forces. If there is substantial leakage from the cover gas region to the containment, particularly if the leakage path is sufficient for containment air to circulate back through the cover gas region, reaction of sodium vapor or sodium aerosols with air and moisture can produce sodium oxide aerosols, which can grow by agglomeration. Other aerosols produced by condensation of radionuclide vapors can co-agglomerate with the sodium oxide aerosols. Gravitational settling and the removal of airborne radionuclides can substantially reduce the inventory of radionuclides available to leak to the environment. Multi-aerosol models, like those in MELCOR, are able to consider the effect of mixing of aerosols with different initial size distributions. The use of a single exponential removal constant could either over-estimate or underestimate this effect depending on the degree of conservatism in the removal constant. • Sodium vapor/aerosol interactions with oxygen and water vapor are exothermic, and a significant quantity of airborne sodium could result in a appreciable increase in containment temperature and pressure, possibly increasing the leakage rate to the environment. For this analysis, the design basis leakage rate is assumed (1% vol/day) regardless of the temperature and pressure of containment, which is likely conservative for the transient scenarios analyzed. • Larger sodium oxide aerosols could potentially become trapped in leakage pathways in containment, resulting in leak plugging and reduced radionuclide transport to the environment. This phenomenon is also conservatively ignored.

• Some radionuclide chemical forms may decompose following interactions with oxygen, forming more volatile radionuclide forms. The SRT code does not take into account the chemical form of a radionuclide, and assesses radionuclide removal due to deposition with a single exponential decay constant. This is likely conservative for most airborne radionuclides, but there are likely exceptions.

As described, the sum total of the impact of ignoring chemical interactions with oxygen in the containment is likely conservative, but that is not true for all cases, such as the formation of more volatile radionuclide forms.

As with the analysis of the cover gas region, a single exponential decay constant was utilized to address the deposition of non-noble gas radionuclides. Specifically, a decay constant of 5.5E-5 per second was chosen, based on an analysis of past data, described in Appendix A.4.

div.head: PLOF+
div.p: The containment analysis assessed the four PLOF+ cases outlined in Table 2-39. Detailed results for cases 2 and 4 are presented here. Figure 2-32 shows the time history of several selected radionuclides within the containment. As with the cover gas region analysis, the figure shows the total inventory within the containment, and the quantity removed due to decay, deposition, and leakage for each time step (1 hour). Due to the assumption of perfect mixing in both the cover gas region and containment, radionuclides begin to enter the containment soon after the initial release into the cover gas region. The noble gases, once in containment, are released to the environment according the containment leakage rate, with only radioactive decay reducing the inventory. For non-noble gas radionuclides, deposition is a major removal pathway, resulting in essentially negligible releases to the environment after approximately 100 hours. Figure 2-33 shows the fractional releases to the environment, in terms of total core inventory. By far, the largest fractional release come from the noble gases, as there is no removal mechanism in the containment other than decay.

div.head: Cesium
div.p: Hour Activity (Ci) Lastly, Table 2-42 provides a summary of the cumulative PLOF+ radionuclide release to the environment over the seven day analysis period. As the results show, in terms of activity, the noble gases dominate the release. There is no change in noble gas release between cases 1 and 2, and cases 3 and 4, as the change in assumption regarding radionuclide entrainment within the bubble does not impact the noble gases. However, there is a change in the release of non-noble gases due to the increase in bubble transport. Section 2.9 will discuss the difference between the releases in more detail, including the importance of the modeling assumptions and their impact. 2-40), as it is the case with highest release levels. As with the cover gas region analysis, a significant amount of decay occurs within the containment, since the radionuclide release occurred while the reactor was at power. As with the PLOF+ analysis, the release of non-noble gases becomes negligible by 100 hours, while the release of the noble gases obtains a steady state value based on the containment leakage rate and the decay of longer-lived radionuclides.

Complete UTOP+ release results are presented in Table 2-43, which exhibit trends similar to that of the PLOF+ transient. In terms of activity, the noble gases dominate the release, even in the cases with "all" in the bubbles (cases 2 and 4). Section 2.9 will discuss the results in greater detail when reviewing offsite dispersion.

div.head: Summary
div.p: Although many of the same phenomena experienced during the cover gas region analysis are also applicable to the containment analysis, they are not repeated here. However, there are several phenomena that are unique to the containment analysis, as shown in Table 2-44. The temperature and pressure response of containment was not modeled directly for the analysis here (as leakage rates were temperatureand pressure-independent), but such modeling will be available in a new version of MELCOR. The same is true of chemical interactions with oxygen in the containment, as MELCOR will be able to address this phenomenon directly. Lastly, an assumed value was utilized for containment leakage for the SRT code, but MELCOR will be able to model temperature-and pressure-dependent leakage to the environment.

div.head: Offsite Dispersion Analysis
div.p: The offsite dispersion analysis was conducted utilizing the code WinMACCS. There are many uncertainties related to the offsite dispersion of radionuclides following a core damage transient. The analysis presented in this section is provided as demonstration of the analysis tools for an SFR MST calculation. The resulting dose findings are heavily dependent on the input assumptions and should not be interpreted as an indication of regulatory acceptance.

div.head: Methodology
div.p: The offsite dispersion analysis requires the output of the containment analysis, plus siting properties. As shown in Table 2-45, there are many phenomena that impact the dispersion of radionuclides offsite. However, most of these phenomena are not unique to SFRs, and are well-characterized from LWR studies. This is not true of all phenomena though, as a metal fuel SFR radionuclide release may have different chemical interactions (and forms) than those radionuclides released following LWR transients, and the applicability of existing dose conversion factors likely requires further assessment.

div.head: Dose Factors Dose conversion factors for radionuclides þ
div.p: The offsite dispersion analysis was performed using WinMACCS [35], with a calculation of total effective dose equivalent (TEDE) of the maximally exposed offsite individual (MOI) at several distances from the plant. The selection of this criteria was made based on 10CFR50.34 (a)(1) [36], which contains two dose requirements during a fission product release:

1) An individual located at any point on the boundary of the exclusion area for any 2-hour period following the onset of the postulated fission product release, would not receive a radiation dose in excess of 25 rem TEDE.

2) An individual located at any point on the outer boundary of the low population zone, who is exposed to the radioactive cloud resulting from the postulated fission product release (during the entire period of its passage) would not receive a radiation dose in excess of 25 rem TEDE.

These are not the only regulatory criteria that would be applicable for the licensing of an SFR (see ref [37] for more examples), but they provided a straightforward point of comparison for the offsite dispersion analysis conducted here.

WinMACCS addresses many of the phenomena noted in Table 2-45, and as a popular computational tool for the assessment of offsite dispersion, there are many documents available that describe the models contained within. The focus of the current discussion is the possibility of SFR-specific factors that could impact the offsite dispersion analysis. For example, the radionuclide aerosols released from containment may be of different size and density than those typically released following an LWR transient. However, WinMACCS allows the specification of these parameters, which would accommodate an SFR analysis, if such information was known. Similarly, custom dose conversion factors can be utilized in WinMACCS, as those currently available for the code (such as FGR-13 [38]) may not be directly applicable for the chemical form and species of radionuclide release from an SFR. This possibly discrepancy is not addressed in detail here, as it would likely require significant effort to determine if the chosen dose conversion factor database adequately represents the SFR source term with regard to radionuclide form.

The first step of the offsite dispersion analysis was to down-select from the list of over 700 radionuclides tracked throughout the trial MST analysis. WinMACCS is limited to 150 isotopes per calculation. While separate calculations can be performed and combined to allow for the treatment of more isotopes, an assessment of those isotopes released for the trial MST calculation found only 138 isotopes of importance to offsite dose 23 . Table 2-46 contains the major WinMACCS input parameters that were used for the analysis. When possible, conservative assumptions were utilized. Seven plume releases was assumed (one for each of the seven days assessed following fuel pin failure), with each plume release lasting one day. The fraction of each radionuclide released during each of the seven plumes was calculated based on the releases from containment for each time period (Section 2.8).

div.head: PLOF+
div.p: The results of the PLOF+ offsite dispersion analysis can be seen in Figure 2-41, for all four cases from Table 2-39. Distances were selected between 100m and 4,830m (3 miles) from the release site. Both the mean values and 95 th percentiles (from the meteorology sampling) are shown. As the figure illustrates, offsite doses are very small, even at distances near the plant, for cases 1 and 2. The difference in assumptions regarding the amount of radionuclides that become entrained in bubbles within the core (the difference between cases 1 and 2), results in approximately an order of magnitude increase in offsite dose.

There is a larger increase in dose between cases 1 and 3, than between cases 1 and 2, since the increase in reactor head leakage in case 3 is approximately two orders of magnitude. When accounting for the change in magnitude regarding the assumption, the increases resulting from the change in the bubble entrainment assumption, and the increases due to the assumption regarding reactor head leakage are very similar. This indicates that the assumptions associated with bubble entrainment (and transport) can be as impactful on offsite dose as the assumptions related reactor head leakage. The only case that resulted in offsite doses above 25 rem was case 4 ("all" in bubble, and "large" reactor head leakage), but only at a distance of 100m and 200m from the release site. In general, the offsite doses are much lower than that of the PLOF+ transient, as far fewer fuel pins failed during the transient, even though the radionuclide release fractions from those pins was high due to the occurrence of fuel melting. The impact of the assumption regarding radionuclide entrainment within bubbles is less than an order of magnitude, and similar to the increase in dose due to the assumption regarding reactor head leakage (when normalized for the magnitude of increase). The resulting dose for all four cases, even at distances very near the release site, are significantly less than 25 rem.

div.head: Summary
div.p: There are many phenomena that can impact the assessment of offsite dose. However, the review here only addresses those phenomena that may be unique to SFR radionuclide releases. Modeling concerns related to general phenomena, such as plume dispersal, meteorology, etc., are well documented elsewhere. For metal fuel, pool-type SFR offsite dispersion analysis, there are three major concerns, as shown in Table 2-47, which all involve the chemical and physical characteristics of the released radionuclides.

The first issue relates to the characteristics of those radionuclides released from the plant, such as aerosol size and density. Due to the presence of sodium vapor/aerosols associated with the release within the containment, aerosol characteristics may deviate from those historically assumed for LWRs. It is likely that the presence of sodium aerosols will result in aerosol agglomeration, but it is difficult to assess the extent to which this factor would distort the applicability of LWR characteristics. Aerosol wet and dry deposition factors from NUREG-1150 and the SOARCA study were chosen, but it is not clear whether these choices are conservative or optimistic for SFR analyses as the particle size distributions are uncertain.

The second issue is the continued possibility of chemical interactions with released radionuclides. If there is a large quantity of sodium released to the containment, it may interact with all available oxygen, limiting further radionuclide-oxygen reactions. Therefore, there is a possibility of continued chemical reactions upon release from containment. As with chemical interactions in the cover gas and containment, it is difficult to determine the cumulative effect of these phenomena, and whether the assumptions utilized here (essentially ignoring this possibility) is conservative in terms of offsite consequence. Unlike the first issue, WinMACCS is not well suited to address the possibility of chemical interactions during radionuclide release.

Lastly, the dose conversion factors utilized for the present analysis are based on studies that were focused on LWR radionuclide release. Again, the physical and chemical form of radionuclide release from an SFR could impact the dose conversion factors. However, it may require a substantial effort to assess this phenomenon in detail.

div.head: Sensitivity Calculation
div.p: As described in Section 1.2, a sensitivity calculation was performed to provide information regarding the importance of particular radionuclides and transport/retention phenomena to offsite consequence. The results of this study are utilized in Section 4 to prioritize gaps identified during the MST trial calculation. The remainder of this section is organized in the following fashion:
3.1 Study Approach -A description of the study motivation, along with a review of the transients analyzed.

div.head: Source Term Decomposition
div.p: -A summary of the transport/retention phenomena and how they were modeled for the sensitivity analysis.

div.head: Base Cases -
div.p: The findings of eight base cases examined using the simplified sensitivity analysis tool.

div.head: Sensitivity Analysis
div.p: -A description of series of sensitivity cases to explore the importance of different phenomena.
Findings -A summary of the analysis findings.

div.head: Study Approach
div.p: Prior to the licensing of an SFR, it will be necessary to develop the technical basis for a MST methodology that would be used in support of a license application. Much of the existing technical basis that has been previously developed has been recently identified in the reports ANL-ART-3 and ANL-ART-38. The magnitude of the research effort undertaken by the U.S. NRC and the nuclear industry in the development of a source term modeling capability for LWRs was very large. The NUREG-1465 report [16] provided the nuclear industry with an Alternative Source Term that was prepared as an alternative to the TID-14844 [42] source term approach, which had been used at the time when most operating plants in the U.S. were first licensed. The NUREG-1465 source terms were based on sensitivity studies performed with the NRC's Source Term Code Package (STCP) [43], which was the predecessor to the MELCOR code [32]. Expert elicitation was used to characterize the range of epistemic uncertainty. Within the U.S., the source term modeling capability has effectively been incorporated into the MELCOR2 (NRC) and MAAP5 (industry) [44] computer codes. The most recent comprehensive examination of LWR source terms was performed by Sandia National Laboratories within the NRC's SOARCA study [45]. A source term analysis capability comparable to the MELCOR code will likely be required for SFRs but with more limited funding than what was available to support LWRs. To help prioritize future additional SFR source term research activities, a sensitivity and uncertainty analysis study has been completed as described in this section.

Although LWRs were designed using the concept of defense-in-depth employing multiple barriers to the release of radionuclides in an accident, early probabilistic risk analyses indicated that in the dominant severe accident scenarios, the primary system boundary was in a failed state at the time of core melting, leaving only the containment system boundary as a barrier to environmental release of radionuclides. In contrast, the SFR designs under development appear to have more robust defense-in-depth features that would reduce the potential for release of radionuclides. For this reason, the approach being taken in this

div.head: Key Project Point
div.p: A simplified source term analysis model was developed to explore the importance of specific radionuclides and transport/retention phenomena with regard to offsite consequence.

sensitivity study focuses on the behavior of these barriers. Because of the serial nature of the barriers, their effectiveness in limiting offsite dose can be represented by multiplicative dose-reduction factors. In logarithmic space these factors are additive constants that provide a convenient means of visually displaying how they impact offsite dose.

div.head: Transient Scenarios
div.p: The NRC differentiates between two types of uncertainty, aleatory (variability) uncertainty and epistemic (state of knowledge) uncertainty. Epistemic uncertainties can be reduced by research (experimental or model development). Aleatory uncertainties cannot. The ultimate use of this study will be to assist in the prioritization of research activities. Thus, the focus is on epistemic uncertainties. Although there is variability (aleatory uncertainty) in design features among the different SFR designs under development, within the sensitivity study, the examination focused on only one specific plant design, as with the MST trial calculation described in Section 2. The belief is that there is sufficient similarity among industry designs that the issues and insights obtained would not substantially vary. Another potential source of variability is associated with different transient scenarios. For this reason, the same two transient scenarios chosen for the MST trial calculation were also utilized for the sensitivity calculation (although with slightly different characteristics):
1) PLOF+: It is assumed that over an extended period (e.g., 2 days) the sodium pool heats up to 800°C. All the pins in the core are assumed to fail but there is no melting of fuel.
2) UTOP+: In this case, some melting of fuel occurs (1/3 rd of core) but the primary sodium pool is at near-nominal temperatures.

Consideration must also be given to different modes of SFR operation, such as the burning of actinides extracted from LWR fuel or as a breeder reactor. The inventory of radionuclides in the fuel depends on the radiation history of the fuel. Typically, accident analyses are performed for the inventory at the end of an operating cycle, when the inventory is the largest. The inventory also depends on the mode of operation of the reactor. For this sensitivity study, two inventories were provided by Argonne analysts, one associated with an actinide burner mode of operation and the other for a breeder mode of operation.

div.head: Source Term Model
div.p: The model that was developed for this study should not be considered a MST analysis model. It does not perform a time-dependent analysis of accident phenomenology. Instead, it treats each of the stages of source term progression as consisting of independent first-order processes, in which removal rates by different processes, j, are represented by proportionality constants, λ j . In common practice, the rate of leakage from a containment is treated in terms of fractional release rate per day, e.g. 0.1 volume percent per day. This is actually only true for conditions in which the containment pressure is sufficiently high such that the flow through the leak is choked and not a function of the pressure differential. At lower pressures, the leak rate is less than the "design" leak rate.

The model used in this study, which is described in Appendix B.1, uses design leak rates for the primary system leakage (except when primary system leakage is large) and for the containment leak rate. In a transient scenario, the containment pressure will be high for a limited period of time. For this study, it is assumed that the period of elevated pressure is 24 hours from the time at which fuel failure occurs. Material balance equations are developed for each stage of radionuclide transport, which are integrated over the 24-hour period. Radioactive decay is included in the base case analyses. Aerosol deposition is not considered within the cover gas region. Aerosol deposition is, however, included as a sensitivity study for the containment region for cases in which the primary system boundary is either not credited as a safetygrade boundary or for which primary system integrity is assumed to be lost as a consequence of the accident conditions. In these cases, there could be substantial leakage of sodium to the containment atmosphere, sodium oxidation, aerosol production, aerosol agglomeration, and gravitational settling.

div.head: Importance Measures
div.p: Source terms are used in a variety of ways during the design process and in the licensing and regulatory oversight of nuclear power plants. Typically, TEDE is used as the human health response measure or is a significant contributor to the response measure for these applications. For example, as mentioned in Section 2.9.1, site dose calculations used to determine the exclusion area boundary and low population zone are based on a TEDE limit (25 rem over a specified time period). Comparisons with the NRC's Quantitative Safety Objectives are also based on TEDE for populations within zones in proximity of the plant [46]. For this reason, it is convenient for the purpose of the sensitivity study to develop a radionuclide importance measure that is proportional to TEDE, but does not require consideration of multiple meteorological scenarios.

A major insight obtained from the Fukushima accident is the relative importance of land contamination, relocation of members of the public, and decontamination costs following a radionuclide release. Although there are no direct U.S. regulations concerning land contamination following a radionuclide release, for the research prioritization conducted in Section 4, it is vital to ensure that radionuclides important to land contamination, but potentially of low importance to short-term dose, are not mistakenly excluded. Thus, for the purposes of this sensitivity study, it is also important to develop a measure that is directly associated with land contamination and relocation criteria.

It has been common practice in the development of source terms for licensing purposes or risk assessments to group different elements with common chemical behavior. However, the consequences of an environmental release depend on both the chemical properties and nuclear properties (half-life and mode of decay). For the sensitivity analysis, therefore, it is essential to examine the relative importance of the individual radionuclides rather than considering elemental groupings. In the actual applications of the MSTs, aggregation into groups with common elemental properties may be found to be of value.

Assessing the relative importance of a radionuclide begins with the inventory (curies). The inventory is then multiplied by a weighting factor to account for the relative health impact of exposure on a per curie basis. Four factors are then applied associated with the barriers to release: retention within fuel (complement of release fraction), retention within primary system comprised of retention within the sodium pool (taking into account capture within the pool and re-evolution of radionuclides to the cover gas region) as well as the potential to bypass the pool by transport in noble gas bubbles, retention within the cover gas region, and finally retention within the containment. To a large extent retention within the sodium pool and cover gas region of the primary system are coupled.

div.head: Source Term Decomposition
div.p: As discussed in the preceding section, in developing the NUREG-1465 alternative source term, it was found to be convenient to decompose the source term into constituent factors. This is also convenient for assessing the uncertainties associated with SFR source terms. There is a high level of defense-in-depth in an SFR associated with multiple barriers to the release of radioactive material to the environment. Although there are potential modes of release to the environment that involve other pathways for release of radioactive material to the environment, such as fuel handling accidents, failure of radioactive waste storage tanks, and containment bypass scenarios, that must be considered in a safety analysis report (SAR), the focus of this uncertainty and sensitivity analysis is accidents involving severe fuel damage including clad failure and the potential melting of fuel, release to the primary system sodium, release from the sodium pool to the cover gas region, release through the upper head of the primary vessel to a containment building and release from the containment building to the environment. It is convenient to decompose the release and transport analysis into four factors: release to sodium pool or bypass of the pool, release from sodium pool to cover gas region, release from cover gas region to containment and release from containment to the environment.

div.head: Radionuclide Weights
div.p: Historically, in major risk studies and in the development of alternative source terms, radionuclides have been aggregated into elemental groupings with common chemical characteristics, such as halides. For the purpose of this sensitivity study, the focus is on the behavior and importance of individual radioactive isotopes. Two weighting schemes have been examined. Analyses were performed using the NRC's RASCAL code, Version 4.3 [47]. In the first weighting scheme, 10 8 Ci of each radioisotope was released over a short time period and the dose was calculated at three miles with D stability meteorology and a wind speed of 5 meters per second. The calculation included inhalation dose from the passing cloud and 4 days of ground shine. This calculation was performed with ICRP26/30 dose conversion factors 26 . Although meteorology and distance would have significant impact on absolute doses, the relative doses among different radionuclides are expected to be largely unaffected. The TEDE is the appropriate measure of exposure for site dose calculations, emergency response planning, and for evaluating conformance with probabilistic safety goals. For the noble gases, the external cloud shine controls the dose. For virtually all other radioisotopes, the inhalation dose is dominant.

Ingestion can be an important exposure pathway. In the Chernobyl accident, ingestion of iodine contaminated milk led to measurable increase in thyroid cancers among children in Ukraine and Byelorus. However, the ingestion pathway is a controllable pathway, which for an open society concerned about the health of the public can be managed to assure minimal health impact. Historically, there has been high regulatory interest in radioactive iodine, in particular 131 I, because of the potentially high volatility of iodine in some fuel systems and the propensity for iodine to migrate to the thyroid, potentially leading to thyroid cancer. The TID-14844 source term is almost entirely focused on the release of radioactive iodine and noble gases, and limits the release of other elemental groups that would transport in the form of aerosols to one percent of the core inventory. As the following sensitivity studies show, radioactive iodine is less likely to be a dominant contributor to dose in SFR accidents. The other significant radiological impact of severe accidents is land contamination with the associated need for the relocation of people, loss of productivity, and expense of decontamination. Cesium isotopes, which are also major contributors to TEDE, are important contributors to the impact of land contamination because of their long half-lives and because they are gamma emitters.

div.head: Release from Fuel
div.p: The principal references for assessing the mechanistic release and transport processes in this study of source term sensitivities are two Argonne reports: ANL-ART-3 [5] and ANL-ART-38 [6]. The release of radionuclides from the fuel matrix during normal operation, relocation within the fuel pin, and subsequent release are difficult to address on a first principles basis. There are significant uncertainties associated with chemical reactions among the radionuclides and the fuel matrix. There are, however, a number of experiments that have provided input to assessing the magnitude of release of the key radionuclides. Of particular importance is the change in morphology of the fuel associated with burnup. As described in Section 2.3.1, at moderate to high burnup levels, a network of interconnected porosity develops that results in substantial transport (up to 80 % of the noble gases to the upper and lower plena of the pins). A significant fraction of the cesium isotopes also escapes from the fuel matrix, and dissolves in the sodium bond, and migrate to the upper and lower plena. In contrast, the iodine radionuclides appear to largely remain within the fuel matrix during normal operation. Table 3-1 identifies the principal radionuclides, their inventory, the dose weighting factor, and the weighted dose for each isotope. The striking feature of the weighted inventories is how very large the weighted inventories are of the plutonium, americium, and curium isotopes in comparison with weighted inventories of other radionuclides. This is because of the very large inhalation dose associated with these alpha emitting radionuclides per curie inhaled. As will be shown later in this section, the overall importance of these radionuclides can be substantially reduced by factors associated with their transport and release to the environment.

In ANL-ART-38, bounding values for fuel release fractions are assessed for different elements based on a review of the existing database. The maximum expected fuel release fractions were assessed for four conditions: normal operation (500 o C), eutectic formation (700 o C), fuel melting (1100 o C) and high temperatures (1300 o C). Table 3-3 shows the assessed release fractions for the fuel melting condition and clad eutectic failure, which are representative of the two accident scenarios analyzed in this study.

div.head: Release from Sodium Pool
div.p: During normal operation, radionuclides released from the fuel matrix may transport through interconnected porosity to the gap region and to the upper and lower plena of the fuel pin where they may be dissolved in the sodium bond or react with the sodium bond. This is particularly true of cesium and europium. Following pin failure, the bubble of fission gases and any inert gas pre-pressurizing the pin will be rapidly released to the fuel channel. As will be discussed in Section 3.2.4, regarding bypass of the sodium pool, the effect of discharge of gas from the plena of fuel pins on flow in the channel, voiding of the channel, and the disruption of the column of liquid above a fuel channel are highly uncertain. However, the potential exists for some fraction of the radionuclides released from the fuel to be transported to the cover gas region without being captured in the pool.

Any radionuclides dissolved in the sodium bond material at the time of pin failure are likely to be carried with the sodium bond material and may be deposited in the sodium pool. If some fragmentation of the bond sodium occurs at the time of pin depressurization, the associated aerosols would be large and would be expected to be transported to the surface of gas bubbles and trapped in the pool by inertial forces. Depending on the chemistry of the radioisotopes released, they may dissolve in the sodium, react with the sodium or potentially be present in the form of small suspended particles, or they may react chemically with structures. At the upper surface of the pool there is a continual flux of sodium evaporating from the pool into the cover gas region and a continual flux of sodium vapor returning to the pool. If the cover gas region remains intact, an equilibrium is established. If there is a significant pathway for release through the head region, sodium vapor and gases in the cover gas region can escape to the containment region, carrying radioactive material with it. If the leakage path to the containment is small, the offsite consequences of the accident will be minor. The larger the leak path, the greater the net vaporization of sodium from the pool and the greater the net vaporization of dissolved radionuclides from the pool. In the report ANL-ART-3, relative fractional releases of key elements are compared with the fractional release of sodium. By examining these data at low fractional sodium release levels, coefficients were developed for the fractional release of each elemental group for a given fractional loss of sodium from the pool, as presented in Table 3-3. Raoult's law (Eq. 1) relating the relative releases of solute materials to the relative vapor pressures of pure substances can be used to bound the release of the solute material. This approach was used to extend Table 3-3 to other elemental groups as designated in the table.
where, ! "# = vapor pressure of component i in cover gas region ! %# = saturated vapor pressure of component i & ",()*+ = mole fraction of component i in condensed phase

Based on Raoult's Law there would be effectively no release of either the americium group or plutonium group of radionuclides by evaporation from the sodium pool. In performing the sensitivity study, it must be recognized that there are other potential mechanisms for the release of radioactive material from the pool beyond evaporation, as described in Section 2.6.1. Since the purpose of this sensitivity study is to identify those radionuclides and mechanisms that have the greatest impact on offsite dose, it is possible to use a bounding value for those unanalyzed mechanisms.

In the sensitivity study, two principal parameters are examined: fraction of failed fuel and percent sodium released to the containment. Two radioactive isotopes of sodium, 22 Na and 24 Na, are created during normal operation as the sodium is irradiated by neutrons as it flows through the core. Based on design values for past Argonne SFR designs [48], importance of the release of these radionuclides in assessing the relative importance of radionuclides in the sensitivity study has been examined. The expected operational activity level of 24 Na is 11.2 Ci/kg and of 22 Na is 1.1E-3 Ci/kg. Knowing the mass of sodium in the primary system, it is possible to calculate the total radioactive sodium inventory. However, in the analysis of sodium retention and evaporation conducted here, it assumed that only half of the liquid sodium in the pool is associated with the release to the cover gas region. If there is substantial fuel damage and release of cesium isotopes to the pool, the contribution of the sodium isotopes to the release to containment will be negligible relative to the release of cesium isotopes, in part because of the higher fractional release of cesium per percent sodium release and the higher dose weighting factors for the cesium isotopes relative to the weighting factors for the sodium isotopes.

div.head: Bypass of Sodium Pool
div.p: During normal operation, the release of noble gas fission products to the plenum region of the fuel pin leads to a substantial increase in the internal pressure of the pin. If fuel pins fail during a transient, which is likely to occur near the top of the fuel column, the gases in the fuel pin will expand and expel the bond sodium above the fuel column (which can contain radionuclides released from the fuel during operation). The released gases, which contain radionuclide vapors and aerosols, can expand across multiple pins within an assembly. If expanded to atmospheric pressure, the volume of gases released from an assembly would be greater than the volume of sodium in the 10 meter-high column directly above the fuel assembly. Thus, it appears likely that failure of fuel pins will lead to extreme turbulence and mixing of the pool, as well as pressurization of the cover gas region. It is difficult to model the capture of aerosols and radionuclide vapors that would occur in this phase of the accident.

Argonne staff have developed a bubble transport model to assess the fraction of aerosols captured in the pool. The equations for diffusion, inertial deposition, diffusiophoresis, thermophoresis and gravitational settling within a bubble are well known mechanisms [20]. The size of the bubble can be assessed from stability considerations and the rise velocity of the bubble related to its size. However, when taking into account non-spherical bubble geometry, induced flow patterns within the bubble, and mechanisms affecting bubble formation and breakup there is significant uncertainty associated with the assessment of decontamination factors. Furthermore, it is not clear how applicable an isolated bubble model is to the time period immediately following pin failure or during later stages of an accident in which radionuclides continue to be evolved. At the time of pin failure, the released gases may appear more like a jet than a bubble depending on the characteristics of pin failure. The volume of released gases may rapidly break into a swarm of smaller bubbles in the open sodium pool region above the core. There is inadequate modeling and validation of the conditions associated with this phase of an accident to accurately assess the associated decontamination factors. It is clear, however, that pool temperature relative to the initial conditions in the bubble has a major impact on the magnitude of decontamination factors, associated with diffusiophoretic and thermophoretic effects. For the purposes of this study, bypass of the pool is treated parametrically using results of Argonne bubble transport analyses to represent the lower end of bypass fraction.

When the bubble breaks the surface of the sodium pool, some of the liquid sodium at the surface of the bubble can be aerosolized as a splash which can carry radioactive material into the cover gas region in the released droplets. The sensitivity model does not explicitly include this contribution to bypass.

Many radionuclides are released as vapors from over-heated fuel. Whether they are in an elemental form or have reacted with other chemicals to form compounds depends on chemical kinetics and timing. Best estimates of the chemistry of the released vapors can be made using chemical thermodynamic equilibrium codes. The results of these analyses can provide insights but are not definitive. As the released vapors move toward colder regions within a fuel pin, the vapors will condense to form aerosols depending on their vapor pressure relative to the saturation pressure at that temperature. Released radionuclides may condense homogeneously within the vapor space of the fuel pin or heterogeneously onto other aerosols or surfaces. Condensed aerosols are typically very small, e.g. on the order of 0.1 micron. This happens to be near the minimum of the curve of decontamination factor (DF) as a function of aerosol size that is most likely to transport to the surface of the sodium pool in bubbles without being captured in the pool [49].

div.head: Release from Cover Gas Region
div.p: Radionuclides reach the cover gas region either by evolving from the pool, which is treated in the sensitivity model as occurring in proportion to sodium evolution, or by bypassing the sodium pool. It is assumed that the system is designed with primary system boundary as a safety grade system with a design release rate of 0.1 v/o per day at a specified pressure. In the analysis model, no credit is given for retention of aerosols or vapors on structures within the cover gas region. For the case studies discussed in Section 3.4, consideration is given to two cover gas region leakage conditions. In one set of base cases, the cover gas region leaks into the containment region at the specified leak rate for the duration of the event. The partial pressure of sodium vapor is maintained at the saturation pressure (at the pool temperature) by net evaporation. The amount of radionuclide release of species that volatilize from the pool is proportional to the leakage of sodium.

In another set of base cases, it is assumed that the integrity of the cover gas region is compromised, such that a substantially larger leakage of sodium occurs to the containment. This can also be considered a design variation in which the primary system is not credited as a low leakage barrier. Again, the leakage to containment of other radionuclides is proportional to the sodium loss from the pool. For the PLOF+ scenario with a high pool temperature (830°C) a total leakage of 1% of the upper pool sodium is assumed. At 830°C, the evaporation rate of sodium into an open containment is approximately 30 kg/m 2 -hr [50], which could easily result in a release of 1% over a 24 hour period. At 530°C, the release rate into an open containment is only approximately 0.8 kg/m 2 -hr, which corresponds to slightly less than 0.5% over a 24hour period. For this reason, in the UTOP+ scenario with a failed primary system the total leakage of sodium is limited to 0.5%.

div.head: Release from Containment
div.p: The final barrier for release of radionuclides to the environment is the reactor containment. It is expected that the SFR designs will use traditional, essentially leak tight containments, even though the expected consequences without containment might satisfy regulatory criteria for offsite doses. For the current study, a comparatively high design leak rate of one volume percent release per day is assumed. Assessing the sensitivity to containment leak rate can be determined using a multiplicative factor proportional to the leak rate. By delaying release to the environment, the containment allows time for radioactive decay and for deposition mechanisms, such as gravitational settling, inertial deposition, and thermophoresis to capture aerosols and prevent their release to the environment. The analysis of containment transport and deposition of aerosols is comparatively well-developed. Considerable research effort was dedicated to this area early in the fast reactor development program, including methods development and validation for the treatment of multi-aerosol sources [51]. Some expertise and judgment is required in exercising these models, such as in the identification of shape factors. There are also some residual areas of remaining uncertainty, such as charge effects arising from radioactive decay of aerosol constituents.

div.head: Consequence Metrics
div.p: The dose weighted consequences obtained with the analysis model are intended to illustrate the relative contribution of different radionuclides to the dose (TEDE) to which a member of the public would be exposed, regardless of distance from the plant or meteorology. The model specifically calculates the inhalation dose, cloudshine, and 4-day groundshine to which an individual would be exposed at 3 miles from the plant for D meteorology and a 5 mph wind speed times a normalizing factor of 1x10 8 . 28 Using dose conversion factors obtained from RASCAL analyses associated with one year of groundshine, the sensitivity model also calculates the one-year groundshine dose, again multiplied by a normalizing factor of 1x10 8 . To provide some perspective on whether the total doses are large or small relative to regulatory criteria, approximate conversion factors are used to translate the results of the case studies to regulatory applications, specifically those addressing site dose criteria and emergency planning criteria.

The site dose criteria, described in Section 3.1.3, limit the dose at the boundary of the exclusion area to 25 rem for the worst two hours of the event and at the boundary of the low population zone to 25 rem over the duration of the event. These calculations are performed for site specific conservative meteorology (95 th percentile). From the Gaussian dispersion equation for the transport of radionuclides, the term chi/q (airborne concentration of a radionuclide per unit source at the location of interest) is used to characterize a site based on local meteorology. It is an objective of advanced reactors to substantially reduce the size of the site boundary and emergency planning zone. To provide some perspective on the severity of releases, the dose at 200 meters from the release point is provided by adjusting the 3-mile dose value by the associated chi/q value. The reader should recognize that a detailed analysis for a specific site would be required to obtain an accurate site dose value. This value represents a low population zone dose at this distance. With the simplified model used in this study, doses during the first two hours tend to be small because of the time required for radionuclide concentration to build up in the containment.
